 Our vision 
Our vision of ‘Bringing life to technology™’ is central to how 
we operate. It provides the Group with our common purpose, 
namely ‘we partner with our customers to improve, save and 
protect people’s lives’. It informs our decision making so that 
our innova � ons lead developments in automa � on, healthcare, 
communica � ons, safety, discovery and the environment. 
During the year, we have been embedding our new culture. All 
sta ﬀ  events in both Chelmsford and Grenoble demonstrated that 
our people understand our vision, brand and values and how 
they can play their part in making it real for both our customers 
and their colleagues.
Our strategy 
 Our focus on our customers is at the core of this framework. We 
ac � vely listen to our customers’ feedback and we are responding 
to what they tell us through delivering what our customers value, 
rather than what we seek to achieve technically. The divisions 
are empowered to focus on their customers’ needs and have 
the power and the responsibility for end-to-end delivery to 
customers. Our customers are apprecia � ng the changes we 
have made and this is being demonstrated in the improving 
feedback we receive from them in our annual customer survey 
and increasingly they are looking to work with us as their trusted 
partner for their future developments. We are looking to build 
greater customer in � macy and will con � nue to focus on our 
strategic customers.
We are seeing good progress in embedding our culture, which 
is retaining the best from our engineering heritage whilst 
simplifying processes and building a responsive and energe � c 
organisa � on. Our people have embraced the vision and the new 
brand and are making the change happen. They understand how 
they make a di ﬀ erence to people’s lives working in partnership 
with our customers. We have been consistent in our internal 
communica � ons, with a focus on our founda � ons and values 
and explaining how everyone can play their part. This means our 
people understand what is expected of them and can work more 
e ﬀ ec � vely. 
Our people are encouraged to use their talents to sustain 
innova � on and supply the solu � ons our customers seek. We 
have seen new product introduc � ons par � cularly in Imaging 
and Semiconductors, which have been well received by our 
customers. In our Space Imaging and RF Power customer 
programmes we are working at the cu �  ng edge of the 
technology, delivering high quality bespoke products. We have 
successfully completed the integra � on of AnaFocus which has 
accelerated innova � on within Imaging. We will complete the 
integra � on of SP Devices in the coming year and are already 
seeing the bene  ts that this team brings to the Semiconductors 
division.
We seek to operate with excellence, shown by rigorous 
execu � on driving responsiveness and agility. We have seen 
good progress across the business, with improved performance 
in each of our divisions. Our people are open to doing things 
di ﬀ erently. They can see that their ideas for improvement are 
being listened to and are keen to share these, underpinning our 
drive for opera � onal excellence throughout the Group. As a 
result, we have made signi  cant improvements in areas which 
are cri � cal to our customers, including on- � me delivery. We are 
looking for further opera � onal improvement in Space Imaging, 
and to focus on process e ﬀ ec � veness across the Group along 
with a reduc � on in inventory cycle � me.
We will con � nue to focus on delivering organic growth, with

build our acquisi � on pipeline.

 Our value proposi on 
–  what we do and our key drivers 
We provide high reliability semiconductors that meet the 
demanding speci  ca ons of our customers. Our design capability 
is enabling us to partner with customers and move up the value 
chain by providing customers with board-level solu ons and 
specialist applica ons exper se. SP Devices is providing access to 
new applica ons and sectors including test and measurement.
Through our strategic partnerships with Freescale, Everspin, 
Maxim and Micron we provide a range of high reliability versions 
of their standard products for use in aerospace applica ons. Our 
own design high speed data converters provide market leading 
performance for space and radio frequency communica ons. 
We also provide our customers with con nuity of supply for 
components that they value, avoiding risks associated with 
counterfeit products.
 Customers and markets 
We have con nued to focus on mee ng our customers’ 
requirements for high reliability, excellent service and on- me 
delivery. We have focused on our customers by increasing our 
business development resources to be er understand our 
customers’ needs, co-funded developments and strengthened 
our rela onships. We have also con nued our investment in 
growing our key strategic partnerships.
We see con nued ongoing market growth for high reliability 
products in civil avia on applica ons such as  ight control 
computers and engine management systems, driven by civil 
avia on produc on rates which have seen high single  gure 
growth rates. Our own designed space quali  ed data converters 
are winning market share as they enable our customers to 
reduce the size and weight of their satellites and at the same 
 me increase the number of communica on channels. The 
steady demand for products that are provided primarily into 
defence applica ons growth is driven by the  ow down of funds 
into the large defence OEMs.
Our in-house designed high speed data converters provide 
market leading performance for ADCs and DACs for space 
RF communica ons. Our data converters are used by most of 
the major space primes and  er one suppliers, including Boeing 
in the US where we secured a mul -year framework contract 
and Thales in Europe, where we enable high bandwidth radio 
frequency communica on links.
We were pleased to have completed the acquisi on of 
SP Devices in January 2016. SP Devices provides high 
performance sub-system solu ons for analogue to digital 
conversion applica ons. These are used by customers including 
leading original equipment manufacturers across a number of 
sectors, including industrial test and measurement, healthcare, 
communica ons and science. It also brings proven patented 
technology in so ware and board level sub-systems and 
services, which complements and enhances e2v’s broadband 
data converter business.
Opera onal progress 
We have introduced new own design high speed data converters 
and new mul -chip modules which enable our customers’ 
innova on. We have also secured design-ins for our products on 
future programmes for civil aerospace and space applica ons. 
During the year we completed the restructuring of the US 
opera ons and this has delivered cost reduc on and posi ons 
the business for the future.

Corporate Responsibility Review
 At e2v we con � nue to manage our business against responsible 
and sustainable principles. We have strong Corporate 
Responsibility (CR) policies which underpin the way we work

Methodology
We have reported on all of the emission sources required 
under the Companies Act 2006 (Strategic Report and Directors’ 
Reports) Regula � ons 2013, which fall within our  nancial control.
Combus � on of fuel and opera � on of facili � es includes the use 
of natural gas as a fuel, the use of oil for on-site electricity 
genera � on, the emission of process and refrigerant greenhouse 
gases from manufacturing and development ac � vi � es and the 
use of fuel in owned vehicles.
We have used the methods indicated in the DEFRA 
Environmental Repor � ng Guidelines, June 2013 edi � on. Emission 
factors from the UK Government’s ‘GHG Conversion Factors for 
Company Repor � ng’ for the relevant year were used, where 
available. For other factors, the Interna � onal Energy Agency’s 
 gures in ‘CO2 Emissions from Fuel Combus � on, Highlights’

26 26
   P eople 
During 2015 the  rst year par cipants in our Fast Track 
scheme successfully completed the programme. The 
scheme aims to further the careers of our middle to senior 
level managers who are excelling in their current roles and 
are keen to progress their careers in the organisa on. 
11 employees graduated from the scheme during the 
year, and more than half of these individuals have 
either achieved a promo on or have undertaken a more 
challenging role. 
One employee greatly bene   ng from the scheme was 
Farzana Khan, who has been promoted from a role as 
Supply Chain Manager to an IT  Engagement Manager. 
Having been with e2v for  four years, Farzana was keen 
to progress her career and bene  t from some of the 
opportuni es open to employees on the scheme, including 
regular mentoring from our Execu ve Commi ee and high 
pro  le, cross-regional project work. 
In Farzana’s new role, she is focused on driving change 
through IT simpli  ca on, con nuous improvement 
and opera onal excellence across the en re business 
landscape, suppor ng our current and future growth 
agenda.  
Corporate Responsibility Review (con nued)
Supply chain
We use best in class commodity management methodology and 
our procurement teams ensure that our sourcing and supplier 
development strategies are fully aligned with the Company’s 
growth goals and the objec ves of our external and internal 
customers.
Our e2v supplier performance reviews drive con nuous 
improvement by enabling the supplier base to focus on the 
key areas of cost, quality and service, in addi on to promo ng 
environmental, social and ethical best prac ces, while 
implemen ng risk mi ga on plans. 
From a compliance perspec ve, we expect suppliers to 
con  rm to e2v’s legal, commercial and ethical requirements in 
conjunc on with our Corporate Social Responsibility (CR) policy.
Our approach helps us to target a low cost of ownership, whilst 
also ensuring a sustainable, secure supply chain, as well as 
maintaining our exac ng quality standards. 001

Working capital
We have a range of working capital cycles across the divisions 
and businesses. For example we support long term availably 
of product for Semiconductors, o � en holding inventory for a 
number of years. In some of our Imaging sensor lines much of 
the manufacturing is provided by third par � es and we only hold

on customers we have increased inventory levels to improve

reasonable payment terms with our customers for our products. 
Where we provide bespoke products or working on long term 
programmes we seek to obtain advance payments to maintain a 
posi � ve pro  le. In terms of trade payables we pay our suppliers 
in accordance with our agreed terms. Overall we seek to manage 
working capital through the cycle and es � mate that on average 
across the Group three to four months working capital is needed

working capital cycles over the current  nancial year.

from the UK and French governments.
 Viability St a t emen t
In accordance with provision C.2.2 of the UK Corporate 
Governance Code, the Directors have assessed the viability of 
the Group over a three year period, taking into account the 
Group’s current posi � on and the poten � al e ﬀ ect of the principal 
risks documented within the Annual Report. Based on this 
assessment, the Directors con  rm that they have a reasonable 
expecta � on that the Company will be able to con � nue in 
opera � on and meet its liabili � es as they fall due over the period 
to 31 March 2019.
The Directors have determined that a three year period to 
31 March 2019 is an appropriate period over which to provide 
its viability statement. This combines the normal period of the 
Group’s  nancing arrangements, with the average of the range 
of business cycles across the Group and is aligned with the 
Group’s planning cycle.
To allow the Directors the make this assessment, a business 
base case has been prepared . For the  rst year, this is based 
on the detailed budgets for the Group, and the following years 
are taken from the Group’s strategic plan, which  is based on an 
appropriate set of assump � ons for growth, margins, working 
capital, capital expenditure, dividends and other ma � ers that 
could have a signi  cant e ﬀ ect on the  nancial performance 
and liquidity of the Group. Assump � ons have also been made 
in respect of the Group’s ability to secure addi � onal  nancing, 
speci  cally to re  nance the revolving credit facility which expires 
on 28 July 2018, as detailed in note 21 to the  consolidated 
 nancial statements. The resul � ng base case provides the 
Directors with EBITDA, debt and  nance charge headroom 
rela � ve to current bank covenants.
The Directors have made a robust assessment of the principal 
risks facing the Group, including their poten� al impact, and 
the adequacy of the Group’s  nancial headroom rela � ve to 
a severe but plausible combina � on of these risks. While the 
review has considered the principal risks iden �  ed by the Group, 
the following were focussed on for enhanced stress tes � ng: 
execu � on risks on current and future programmes; technological 
risk, both obsolescence and the poten � al for development 
programmes to fail; supply chain disrup � on and the poten � al for 
product quality or warranty issues; and, the risks from foreign 
exchange movements and the broader economic environment. 
Whilst this review does not consider all of the possible risks 
that the Group could face, the Directors consider that the 
approach adopted and the work performed is reasonable in 
the circumstances of the inherent uncertainty involved and 
that it allows the Board to con  rm that they have a reasonable 
expecta � on that the Group will be able to con � nue in opera � on 
and meet its liabili � es as they fall due over the period to 
31 March 2019. 001

governance as set out in the UK Corporate Governance Code 
published by the Financial Repor � ng Council in September 2014 
(the Code). A copy of the Code is available at www.frc.org.uk. 
The Board has been mindful to ensure that the Group complies

Statement of Compliance
The Board con  rms that the Group has complied with the 
relevant provisions set out in the Code throughout the year

publica � on of this Annual Report.
Leadership
The role of the Board
The role of the Board is to provide entrepreneurial leadership of 
the Group within a framework of prudent and e ﬀ ec � ve controls 
which enables risk to be assessed and managed. Collec � vely 
the Board is responsible for the long term success of the 
Company. The names, biographical details and signi  cant � me 
commitments of the members of the Board are set out on pages 
 3 2 an d  33 .
The Board sets the Group’s strategic aims, ensures the necessary 
 nancial and human resources are in place to enable the Group 
to meet its objec � ves, and reviews management’s performance. 
The Board is responsible for se �  ng the Group’s values and 
standards and ensuring that the Group’s obliga � ons to its 
shareholders and other stakeholders, including employees, 
customers, suppliers and the wider community, are understood 
and met.
The Chairman’s primary role includes ensuring that the 
Board func � ons properly, that it meets its obliga � ons and 
responsibili � es and that its organisa � on and mechanisms 
are in place and working e ﬀ ec � vely. The Chairman is also 
an ambassador for the Company to shareholders and wider 
stakeholders. There is no Deputy Chairman.
Non-Execu � ve Directors are responsible for exercising 
independent and objec � ve judgement in respect of Board 
decisions, developing strategy with Execu � ve Directors and 
scru � nising the performance of management in mee � ng 
agreed goals and objec � ves and monitoring the repor � ng of 
performance.
The appointment of Carla Cico as a Non-Execu � ve Director 
brings relevant experience in technological  elds adjacent to 
those in which the Group currently operates, together with a 
global business perspec � ve.
The Group CEO’s primary role is to provide overall leadership 
and vision in developing, with the Board, the strategic direc � on 
of the Group. The Execu � ve Directors are responsible for the 
management of the overall business, ensuring strategic and 
business plans are e ﬀ ec � vely implemented subject to agreed 
levels of authority and ensuring results are monitored and 
reported to the Board and  nancial and opera � onal objec � ves 
are a � ained.
There exists a clear division of responsibili � es between the 
Chairman and the Group CEO, which are set out in wri � ng and 
agreed by the Board.
The Senior Independent Director acts as a sounding board to 
the Chairman and serves as an intermediary for other Directors 
where necessary. The Senior Independent Director is also 
available to shareholders should they have any concerns and 
where contact through the normal channels is inappropriate, 
and is responsible for leading the review of the Chairman’s 
performance as part of the annual Board evalua � on.
Opera on of the Board
The Board’s responsibili � es are discharged by way of monthly 
Board reviews (except in August and December) and other 
Board mee � ngs as required to approve ma � ers beyond the 
authority limits of the Group CEO. The Board also convenes

resolu � ons to deal with speci  c business requirements. There 
were ten general monthly Board mee � ngs during the year. At the 
monthly Board mee � ngs, the Non-Execu � ve Directors review 
the reports presented to them by the Group CEO and Group 
Finance Director, which include a review of the  nancial results. 
This review compares the current year with the previous year 
and the annual opera � ng plan as well as a current year forecast 
and order book levels.
In addi � on there are mee � ngs of the Commi � ees of the Board 
as well as regular business division and func � on reviews where 
senior members of execu � ve management make presenta � ons 
to the Directors.
Measures are taken to ensure that no con  icts of interest 
arise at Board and Commi � ee mee � ngs, and that quorum 
requirements are sa � s  ed at all mee � ngs.
The Board has adopted a formal schedule of ma � ers detailing 
key aspects of the Company’s a ﬀ airs reserved for it to approve, 
which is reviewed annually to ensure it remains appropriate. 
Items requiring Board approval are either agreed at the monthly 
Board mee � ngs, at intervening mee � ngs speci  cally arranged

Shareholder Informa � on Str a t egic R e port Governance Financials
All of the current Non-Execu � ve Directors have been appointed 
within the last six years. The Non-Execu � ve Directors (including 
Neil Johnson upon his appointment as Chairman on 31 March 
2013) are all considered to be independent of management and 
free from any business or other rela � onship that could materially 
interfere with the exercise of their independent judgement.
The Board has considered the other appointments by the 
Directors, details of which are contained in their biographies on 
pages  32 and  33 and has con  rmed that each is able to devote 
su ﬃ  cient � me to ful  l the du � es required under the terms of 
their contracts or le � ers of appointment.
In line with the Code, the Company’s Ar � cles of Associa � on 
require that Directors submit themselves for re-elec � on on an 
annual basis.
The composi � on of the Board is intended to ensure that its 
membership represents a mix of backgrounds and experience 
that will enhance the quality of its delibera � ons and decisions. 
Diversity in board composi � on is an important driver of board 
e ﬀ ec � veness. In looking for prospec � ve Directors, there is 
regard to the skills of the Board at that � me and the need to 
address longer term succession and business priori � es. The 
annual formal evalua � on of the Board, Board Commi � ees 
and individual Directors’ performance takes Board diversity 
into account and is instrumental in iden � fying any new skill 
requirements, as well as possible shortcomings, gaps or 
ine ﬃ  ciencies.
The current female representa � on on the Board is 29%. The 
Board recognises the importance of gender diversity at the level 
below the Board and is commi � ed to ensuring the appropriate 
level of gender diversity, in par � cular at senior management 
level where female representa � on is 24%. Further informa � on 
on the total number of women employed by the Group is 
provided in the Corporate Responsibility Review.
The Company Secretary reports to the Chairman on governance 
ma � ers and is responsible for keeping the Board as a whole up 
to date on all legisla � ve, regulatory and governance ma � ers 
and is responsible for suppor � ng the Chairman and other 
Directors as necessary, including the management of Board and 
Commi � ee mee � ngs, their evalua � on and advising on Directors’ 
du � es. The appointment and removal of the Company Secretary 
is a ma � er for the Board as a whole.
Con  icts of interest
In line with the Companies Act 2006, the Company has 
established a robust procedure requiring Directors to seek 
appropriate authorisa � on prior to entering into any outside 
business interests. Actual or poten � al con  icts of interest are 
reviewed by the Board.
Induc on and training
New directors undertake an induc � on programme upon their 
appointment to the Board covering the ac � vi � es of the Group 
and its key business and  nancial risks, the terms of reference 
of the Board and its Commi � ees and the latest  nancial 
informa � on of the Group. Ongoing training is provided as 
necessary and the requirement for this is assessed through the 
annual performance review as well as on an ad hoc basis. This 
includes all training required to perform the role. Directors have 
access to and may consult with the Company Secretary at any 
� me on ma � ers related to their role on the Board. All Directors 
have access to independent professional advice at the Group’s 
expense where they judge it necessary to discharge their du � es, 
with requests for such advice being authorised by the Chairman 
or the Company Secretary.
Performance evalua on of the Board
The Chairman and Company Secretary undertook a performance

details of those risks and the Group’s approach to mi ga ng

The Group’s key risk management processes and system of 
internal control procedures include the following:
Management structure:
The Group has adopted procedures for the delega on of 
authority and authorisa on levels, segrega on of du es and 
other control procedures. Appointments to the most senior 
management posi ons within the Group require Board approval.
Iden  ca on and evalua on of business risks:
The major  nancial, commercial, legal, regulatory and opera ng 
risks within the Group are iden  ed through a range of review 
mee ngs at the relevant management level. Senior management 
are also involved in the prepara on of an annual risk assessment 
report which is reviewed by the Board.
Informa on and  nancial repor ng systems:
The Group’s comprehensive planning and  nancial repor ng 
procedures include detailed opera onal budgets for the year 
ahead and a three year rolling business plan, both of which 
are approved by the Board. Performance is monitored on a 
regular basis through monthly repor ng and regular forecast 
updates. Management and specialists within the Finance 
Department are responsible for ensuring the appropriate 
maintenance of  nancial records and processes that ensure all 
 nancial informa on is relevant, reliable, in accordance with the 
applicable laws and regula ons, and distributed both internally 
and externally in a  mely manner. A review of the consolida on 
and  nancial statements is completed by management to 
ensure that the  nancial posi on and results of the Group are 
appropriately re  ected. All  nancial informa on published by 
the Group is subject to the approval of the Audit Commi ee.
Investment appraisal:
All capital expenditure and research and development projects 
require detailed wri en proposals and go through strict 
authorisa on processes. All acquisi ons are subject to Board 
approval and commercial, legal and  nancial due diligence is 
carried out if a business is to be acquired.
Rela ons with shareholders
The Annual Report and Financial Statements, Half-Yearly 
Financial Report, Preliminary Announcement and Interim 
Management Statements provide investors with a balanced view 
of the Group’s ac vi es and performance. The principal form of 
communica on with private investors is the Company’s website 
which is updated regularly with Company informa on.
The Chairman is available to ins tu onal investors and the 
principal contact points are the Group CEO and Group Finance 
Director. The Senior Independent Director is also available to 
whom investors may address any concerns they may have. 
Presenta ons are given to individual ins tu ons, or on a group 
basis if preferred, following the announcement of half-yearly 
and full year results. Site tours and ad-hoc mee ngs are also 
arranged where requested.
The AGM provides the Board the opportunity to meet informally 
and communicate directly with private shareholders. Vo ng 
at the AGM is conducted by way of a show of hands in order 
to encourage ques ons from and interac on with private 
shareholders. Proxy votes lodged on each AGM resolu on are

Appointment, independence and e ﬀ ec � veness

Introduc on

The Directors’ Annual Report on Remunera � on (pages  54 to  66) sets out how the policy was implemented for the year ended 
31  March 2016 and this will be put to an advisory shareholder vote at the 2016 AGM.
Performance remunera on during the year
The results for the year ended 31 March 2016 re  ect a good performance for the year. The Group reports revenue of £236m, an 
increase of 5% on last year. Adjusted opera � ng pro  t of £42m, an increase of 5%, re  ects this good opera � ng performance. Cash 
genera � on during the year delivered opera � ng cash in  ow of £33m, with the Group repor � ng as at 31 March 2016 net borrowings of 
£21m, a � er the purchase of SP Devices.
Bonuses for the year ended 31 March 2016 were based solely on adjusted opera � ng pro  t performance, with up to 100% of salary 
in cash for achieving stretch performance and a further 40% of salary (payable in deferred shares) achievable for above stretch 
performance. Notwithstanding adjusted opera � ng pro  t for the year of £42m, 5% growth on prior year, this was below the target 
level of performance required resul � ng in no bonuses being payable to the Execu � ve Directors for the year ended 31 March 2016.
The 2012 Long Term Incen � ve Plan (LTIP) award vested during the year. The award was based 50% on absolute Total Shareholder 
Return (TSR) and 50% on rela � ve TSR performance. The strong performance of the Company over this period has delivered an 89% 
return to shareholders, resul � ng in 81% of the award ves � ng. The Group CEO joined the Group in 2014 and therefore was not a 
par � cipant in the 2012 LTIP award cycle.
As noted in last year’s Annual Report on Remunera � on, the Commi � ee undertook a review of the base salary level for the Group 
CEO during 2015. Following a consulta � on with major shareholders last summer, the Remunera � on Commi � ee approved a one-o ﬀ  
salary increase for the Group CEO, Steve Blair, from £334,750 to £390,000 (e ﬀ ec � ve from 1 October 2015). While the Commi � ee 
originally considered phasing the increase over � me, during the consulta � on exercise a number of our major investors indicated that 
they would be comfortable with a one-o ﬀ  adjustment. The increase has been designed to bring his salary in line with the appropriate 
rate for the role and re  ects Steve’s excep � onal performance since he joined the Group, in re-energising the business and the strong 
improvement this has had on our  nancial and opera � onal performance.
Charles Hindson received a 5% salary increase in October 2015, following a review of individual and Group performance. The 
average increase awarded across the workforce was 2.5% (with actual increases ranging from 0% to 5% depending on individual 
performance).

The Commi ee is not proposing to make any changes to the Remunera on Policy for the year ending 31 March 2017. In terms of how 
the policy will be applied in the year ahead, the key points to note are:
• basic salaries will be reviewed in line with the rest of the Group on 1 October 2016. Increases are expected to be within the normal 
workforce range;
• pension provision will remain at 15% of salary;
• the annual bonus will con nue to be capped at 140% of salary based on a sliding scale of adjusted opera ng pro  t targets. 
Execu ve Directors will earn 50% of salary for achieving target performance and 100% of salary for achieving stretch target. Any 
bonus above 100% of salary (i.e. performance above stretch target) will con nue to be deferred into shares for three years;
• the LTIP awards for 2016 will con nue to be granted as a normal award (100% of salary) and an addi onal award (25% of salary) 
with performance based on earnings per share (EPS) and TSR (each accoun ng for half of the award). The TSR targets for the 
normal and addi onal awards will be the same as those applying to the 2015 awards. The EPS targets for the 2016 awards will 
require adjusted EPS growth of 5% to 13% per annum for the normal awards and 13% to 15% per annum for the addi onal awards. 
This represents a reduc on on the threshold target for the normal awards from 6% to 5% per annum as a result of the challenging 
market and economic condi ons faced by the Company. The stretch target for the normal awards and the target range for the 
addi onal awards are the same those used in prior years. The target ranges for the 2016 awards have been set taking into account 
latest internal and external forecast for the business and the Remunera on Commi ee is sa s  ed that the proposed target range 
is suitably challenging. 
• shareholding guideline, set at two  mes salary, will con nue to operate.
In summary, this has been a challenging year for the Group but our approach to execu ve remunera on con nues to incen vise 
execu ves to build sustainable value for our shareholders over the long term.
Yours sincerely
Krishnamurthy Rajagopal
Chairman of the Remunera on Commi ee

Awards based on performance during the relevant

Performance measures are set annually and pay-outs 
are determined by the Commi ee a er the year end, 
based on performance against those targets. 
A por on of the bonus may be deferred into share 
awards under the Deferred Bonus Plan. The por on 
is determined by the Commi ee for each  nancial 
year and may vary on an annual basis, up to a 
maximum deferral level of 50%.
Bonus awards in deferred shares under the Deferred 
Bonus Plan normally vest three years a er grant.
Bonus awards in deferred shares under the Deferred 
Bonus Plan are normally made in the form of 
condi onal share awards but may be awarded in 
other forms if appropriate (such as nil-cost op ons). 
Nil-cost op ons may normally be exercised un l the 
tenth anniversary of the date of grant. Awards may 
also be sa s  ed in cash.
At the Commi ee’s discre on, dividend equivalent 
payments may be made (in cash or shares) on 
deferred shares, equal to the amount of dividends 
that would have been payable during the period 
between the grant and ves ng of an award. Unvested 
deferred share awards are subject to claw-back 
provisions. 
The Commi ee may cancel or reduce a deferred 
bonus award if the results used to calculate the 
relevant bonus contained a material mis-statement.
Maximum opportunity of up to 140% of base 
salary in respect of any nancial year.
Annual bonus targets are set by the 
Commi ee each year, taking into 
account the Group strategy and 
corporate plan.
When se  ng the targets, the 
Commi ee ensures that they are 
appropriately stretching in the 
context of the corporate plan and 
that there is an appropriate balance 
between incen vising Execu ve 
Directors to meet targets for the 
year, whilst ensuring that they do not

encourage inappropriate behaviours.

 nancial performance measures. 
For achievement of a threshold level 
of performance (the minimum level 
of performance that results in any 
payment), typically no more than 
50% of the maximum will be paid.

For these purposes, payments include the Commi � ee sa � sfying awards of variable remunera � on and, in rela � on to an award over

Group CEO Share Incen ve Plan
The Group CEO Share Incen � ve Plan was a one-o ﬀ  plan to provide, on appointment, the Group CEO with the opportunity to 
demonstrate long term commitment to the Group through a signi  cant personal investment in the Company and to incen � vise 
him to grow shareholder value in the long term. No future awards will be made under the Group CEO Share Incen � ve Plan. A short 
summary of the plan is provided below, with more detailed informa � on provided in the no � ce of the General Mee � ng in November 
2013.
• Ini � al shares were o ﬀ ered on a nil-price op � on basis to match the personal investment made by the Group CEO.
• Based on achievement of share price growth targets over the three-year performance period and subject to a secondary Total 
Shareholder Return (TSR) measure requiring upper decile performance to achieve full ves � ng, both the invested shares and the 
matching shares are eligible to be mul � plied by a maximum of three � mes.
• Ves � ng is dependent on the Group CEO retaining the ini � al personally acquired shareholding.
Awards not subject to performance measures
Shares deferred under the annual bonus are not subject to further performance measures, as they represent the deferred element of 
remunera � on which has already been earned. 
Change of control
Awards under the deferred bonus, LTIP and Chairman and Group CEO Share Incen � ve Plans may be adjusted in the event of a 
varia � on of the Company’s share capital, demerger, delis � ng, special dividend, dividend in specie or other corporate event which may 
a ﬀ ect the current or future value of share awards. 
Explana on of choice of performance measures and how targets are set 
The Commi � ee believes the choice of performance measures for the annual bonus and LTIP represent an appropriate balance 
between the short term and long term focus of the Group’s strategy aims and key performance indicators, as well as an appropriate 
balance between internal and external assessments of performance. When targets are set, the Commi � ee takes into account a 
number of di ﬀ erent factors, including market prac � ce, market expecta � ons and internal business plans and forecasts. 
Remunera on arrangements throughout the Group
Remunera � on arrangements for the wider employee popula � on are based on the principle that reward should help deliver the 
business strategy and should be su ﬃ  cient to a � ract and retain the best talent. To the extent prac � cable, reward prac � ces for 
Execu � ve Directors are cascaded down through the organisa � on, such that where possible employees are incen � vised towards 
common goals.
Throughout the Group, the aim is to provide remunera � on packages that are compe � � ve in the relevant market for that role. 001

Fees
Core element of remunera � on, paid for ful  lling the relevant role. A � racts the appropriate individual to oversee the Group’s business 
strategy.
NEDs receive a basic annual fee, paid monthly, in 
respect of their Board du � es.
Further fees are paid to NEDs in respect of 
chairmanship of Board commi � ees and the role of 
Senior Independent Director. No fees are paid for 
membership of a Board commi � ee.
The Non-execu � ve Chairman receives an all-inclusive 
fee for ful  lling the role of Company Chairman.
Where contractual arrangements allow, further 
daily rate fees may be payable for the provision of 
addi � onal services.
The remunera � on of the Non-execu � ve Chairman is 
set by the Commi � ee. The Execu � ve Directors are 
responsible for determining NED fees.
These fees are the sole element of NED 
remunera � on. NEDs are not eligible for annual 
bonus, share incen � ves, pensions or other bene  ts 
other than the Chairman Share Incen � ve Plan, as set

Chairman Share Incen ve Plan
The Chairman Share Incen � ve Plan was approved by shareholders at the Company’s July 2013 AGM. No further awards will be made 
under this plan. The key features of the plan are described below (a more detailed summary is provided in the July 2013 AGM No � ce 
available on the Group’s website).
The plan provides the Chairman with the opportunity to demonstrate long term commitment to the Company through a signi  cant 
personal investment in the Company and to incen � vise him to grow shareholder value in the long term.
• A con � ngent award of shares was made, dependent upon a personal investment made by the Chairman and the achievement 
of performance targets over a three-year performance period. A total poten � al award of 720,000 nil-cost op � ons was made, 
comprising up to six � mes the number of shares purchased by the Chairman.
• Ves � ng is condi � onal on the Chairman retaining the ini � al personally acquired shareholding.
• Ves � ng is also subject to certain performance condi � ons and targets. Share price growth targets are set subject to a secondary 
TSR performance measure requiring upper decile performance to achieve maximum ves � ng.
Recruitment policy 
Principles
The Group’s recruitment policy is based on a number of key principles:
• To provide a remunera � on package which is su ﬃ  cient to a � ract, retain and mo � vate key talent, whilst at all � mes having regard to 
the best interests of the Group and shareholders and ensuring that the Group pays no more than is necessary.
• In determining an appropriate remunera � on package, the Commi � ee takes into account a number of factors. These will usually 
include the candidate’s experience and calibre, their loca � on and circumstances, external market in  uences and exis � ng 
arrangements for other Execu � ve Directors.
• Following appointment, the remunera � on arrangements for the individual will typically be in line with the policy set out in the 
Policy Table, or be transi � oned onto these arrangements.
• Where the Company appoints a new Execu � ve Director, the Commi � ee will provide full details of the remunera � on in the next 
Director’s Annual Report on Remunera � on and will seek to provide shareholders with ra � onale for the decisions which were taken.
• The Commi � ee may also consider providing addi � onal bene  ts to expatriate appointments, where appropriate. 001

Directors’ Remunera � on Report (con � nued)
Components and approach
The following table sets out key elements which may be considered by the Commi � ee in determining the remunera � on package. In 
circumstances in which the Commi � ee considers it appropriate, other elements in addi � on to those below may also be considered.
Element of package Approach
Basic salary The level of base salary for any new recruit is set at a level commensurate with calibre and experience.
If it is considered appropriate to set the ini � al salary at a below-market level, then, subject to 
performance, as the individual gains experience a series of greater than usual increases may be required 
to reach an appropriate market compe � � ve level over subsequent years.
Bene  ts New appointments would typically receive bene  ts in line with the Policy table above.
The Commi � ee may consider providing reloca � on expenses and in the case of expatriate appointments, 
other addi � onal bene  ts such as interna � onal school fees and tax advice, where necessary.
Pension New appointments would typically receive pension provision in line with the Policy table.
Annual bonus Maximum annual bonus in line with the Policy table.
Share awards Maximum LTIP award in line with the Policy table.
LTIP awards may be made to any new recruit in line with the policy above and subject to the rules of the 
plan.
Typically, awards will be made in the normal annual cycle following the announcement of the annual 
results. However, at the Commi � ee’s discre � on, awards may be granted at other � mes in the year 
(including on appointment) and the performance period may therefore be adjusted as appropriate.
The maximum level of variable pay which may be awarded in respect of a recruitment event (internal or external), will not exceed 
340% of base salary excluding buy-out awards. This represents the current maximum award under the annual bonus and LTIP.
Buy-out awards
To facilitate recruitment, the Commi � ee may make a one-o ﬀ  award to ‘buy-out’ variable incen � ves which the individual would forfeit 
at their current employer. Typically such awards will be made in the form of shares with appropriate performance measures although 
in certain circumstances some, or all, of the award may be made in cash. This may include the use of the relevant provision in the FCA 
lis � ng rules, allowing for excep � onal one-o ﬀ  awards to be made without prior shareholder approval.
In making such awards, the Commi � ee will give considera � on to relevant factors. These will generally include the propor � on of 
the performance/ves � ng period outstanding and the poten � al value of the forfeited remunera � on, including any performance 
condi � ons a � ached to the forfeited awards and the likelihood of those condi � ons being met.
In cases of an internal hire, any exis � ng variable pay arrangements in rela � on to the previous role will be allowed to pay-out 
according to their terms and may be adjusted to take into account the Board appointment.
In the event of the appointment of a new Non-Execu � ve Director, remunera � on arrangements will be in line with those detailed in 
the Non-Execu � ve Director Policy table on page  49. 001

Directors’ Remunera � on Report (con � nued)
Loss of o ﬃ  ce payment policy 
The Commi � ee takes into account a number of factors when considering leaving arrangements for an Execu � ve Director.
• Where an individual resigns, they will receive no addi � onal payment for loss of o ﬃ  ce.
• Where the individual is dismissed for performance, capability or any other substan � al reason, they will receive no more than their 
statutory / contractual en � tlements, including salary for the relevant no � ce period, car allowance and pension contribu � on.
• Where the individual is dismissed for gross misconduct, they will receive no compensa � on.
• Individuals will not normally be eligible to receive an annual bonus if on the date the bonus is declared they are no longer 
employed by the Company, under no � ce or on garden leave. Where the Commi � ee considers the individual to be a ‘good leaver’, 
in some excep � onal circumstances it may consider the individual eligible for a � me pro-rated annual bonus, determined against 
the relevant performance condi � ons.
• Other payments such as legal and outplacement fees may be paid if it is considered appropriate.
Treatment of outstanding share awards is governed by the relevant share plan rules. These are set out in the table below.
Share plan Leaver treatment
Bonus awarded in shares under the 
Deferred Bonus Plan
All awards lapse unless, at the discre � on of the Commi� ee, the leaver is deemed to be a ‘good leaver’ 
speci  ed as leaving due to ill-health; injury or disability; redundancy; death or; any other reason (except 
for dismissal for misconduct), as determined by the Commi � ee. In such circumstances awards will vest on 
the date of termina � on. 
LTIP All awards will lapse unless, at the discre � on of the Commi� ee, the leaver is deemed to be a ‘good leaver’ 
speci  ed as leaving due ill-health; injury or disability; redundancy; death; the individual’s employing 
business or company ceasing to be part of the Group or; any other reason (except for dismissal for 
misconduct) as determined by the Commi � ee.
Awards will normally vest on the original ves � ng date, unless the Commi � ee determines that awards 
should vest as soon as prac � cable following leaving.
In these circumstances, the Commi � ee will determine the extent to which awards should vest taking into 
account achievement of the relevant performance condi � ons and, unless the Commi � ee determines 
otherwise, the period of � me that has elapsed between grant and the anniversary of the grant date 
following the individual’s departure. Where a par � cipant has died, awards will only be � me pro-rated in 
accordance with the rules where the Commi � ee considers it appropriate.
Awards lapse for other leavers.
Chairman and Group CEO Share 
Incen � ve Plans
If the Chairman or Group CEO dies or leaves as a result of ill-health; injury or disability or for any other

increases within the wider employee popula � on. It also assesses Group performance and a ﬀ ordability within the context of the 
whole employee base.
• Annual bonus – The performance measures and targets that are set for the Execu � ve Directors form the basis for the variable pay 
arrangements in place at the execu � ve commi � ee and senior management levels. The percentage of salary that can be earned 
reduces through the organisa � on to re  ect the relevant level of responsibility.
• LTIP, bene  ts and pensions – Similarly, the same basic principles that govern these addi � onal elements of Execu � ve Director’s 
remunera � on are also used elsewhere in the Group. Award levels are tailored to re  ect seniority level.
Whilst the Commi � ee does not formally consult with employees when se �  ng Execu � ve Director pay, those employees who hold

whenever material changes are under considera � on.
Illustra on of the applica on of remunera on policy

stretching short term and long term performance targets. In reviewing the remunera � on package, the Commi � ee takes into account 
the level of remunera � on which Execu � ve Directors may receive at various levels of performance, to ensure that it is appropriate and

Minor amendments
To aid in the administra on of the Policy set out above, the Commi ee may make minor amendments without obtaining shareholder 
approval. For example, such amendments may include those for regulatory, exchange control, tax or administra ve purposes or to 
take account of a change in legisla on.
Remunera on Commi ee
The Remunera on Commi ee is responsible for recommending to the Board the framework and broad policy for the remunera on 
of the Chairman, Group CEO, Group Finance Director and such other members of the execu ve management as it is requested to 
consider. The remunera on of the Non-Execu ve Directors is a ma er reserved for the Execu ve Directors, subject to shareholder 
consulta on as appropriate.
Members of the Commi ee are appointed by the Board. Krishnamurthy Rajagopal is Chairman of the Commi ee. Its other members, 
who have served on the Commi ee throughout the year ended 31 March 2016, are Kevin Danger  eld and Alison Wood. On 1 April 
2016 Carla Cico was appointed to the Commi ee. The Board considers that all members of the Commi ee comprise independent 
directors. The Commi ee meets at least once a year. The Group CEO is given no ce of all mee ngs, may a end by invita on, and is 
consulted on the remunera on of other execu ves. However, the Group CEO does not take part in discussions that relate directly to 
his own remunera on.
The Commi ee members have no personal  nancial interest (other than as a shareholder), con  ict of interest arising from cross-
directorships with the Execu ve Directors, or involvement in the day to day business of the Group. 001

Shareholder Informa on Str a t egic R e port Governance Financials
When determining the pay of Execu ve Directors, the Commi ee takes into account the pay and employment condi ons of 
employees throughout the Group. In this regard, the Commi ee ensures (via regular interac on with the Group’s human resources 
(HR) teams) that it is kept fully informed of all relevant group wide remunera on related issues and ensures that the same broad 
remunera on principles are used when designing the wider employee remunera on policies. The Chairman of the Remunera on 
Commi ee regularly consults with the Group HR Director, who may a end mee ngs by invita on. The Group Finance Director may 
also a end mee ngs by invita on. The General Counsel and Company Secretary acts as secretary to the Commi ee.
The Commi ee’s terms of reference are available on the Group’s website and include;
• agreeing with the Board the remunera on of the Chairman;
• agreeing with the Board the remunera on of the Execu ve Directors;
• agreeing with the Board the policy for the remunera on of the Company Secretary and other members of the execu ve 
management commi ee as well as reviewing the appropriateness and relevance of the policy;
• determining targets for any performance related pay schemes and approving total annual payments under the schemes;
• reviewing all share incen ve plans, the related performance targets and all awards made under the schemes;
• determining the procedure for ve  ng, authorisa on and reimbursement of claims for all Directors; and
• establishing criteria, terms of reference and selec on and employment of remunera on consultants.
The Commi ee met  ve  mes during the year. Details of a endance at Commi ee mee ngs during the year ended 31 March 2016 
are set on page  38. During the year the Commi ee has considered the appropriateness and relevance of the remunera on policy, the 
Execu ve Directors’ remunera on packages, including base salaries, the grant and ves ng of share-based incen ve awards and the 
amount and basis of performance related bonuses.
Advisors to the Commi ee
The Commi ee requests its advisors to a end mee ngs periodically during the year. The Commi ee retained the services of New 
Bridge Street, a brand of Aon Hewi  Limited, as its independent advisor on remunera on ma ers throughout the year. New Bridge 
Street was appointed as adviser to the Commi ee in November 2014 following a compe  ve tender process. Total fees for advice 
provided to the Commi ee by New Bridge Street were £62,079 (2015: £16,666).
New Bridge Street is a member of the Remunera on Consultants Group and as such operates under the code of conduct in rela on 
to execu ve remunera on consul ng in the United Kingdom. New Bridge Street is a trading name of Aon Hewi  Ltd, part of Aon plc 
(Aon). During the year Aon also provided advice on pensions and risk-bene  t insurance. The Commi ee is sa s  ed that the advice it 
has received from New Bridge Street has been objec ve and independent and that no con  ict of interest arises as a result of these 
services.

Directors’ Remunera � on Report (con � nued)
Basic salary (subject to audit)
The Group’s normal salary review process takes place in the autumn, with any changes e ﬀ ec � ve from 1 October. 
As highlighted in last year’s Annual Statement on Remunera � on, the Commi � ee believed that it was appropriate to review the salary 
for Steve Blair, Group CEO, in the second half of 2015 in light of this policy. Since joining e2v in March 2014, Steve has re-energised 
e2v and made a major posi � ve impact on the Group’s opera � ons, with the  nancial performance improving signi  cantly and the 
Group structure simpli  ed. In November 2014, Steve launched ‘our vision, our future’ focussed on ‘Bringing life to technology’. 
We are pleased with the progress he has made in delivering this vision and the impact of this strategy has been well received by 
shareholders. 
Steve was appointed in March 2014 on a salary of £325,000 which subsequently increased to £334,750 in October 2014. This was 
considered below market against companies of a comparable size and complexity and re  ected that this was his  rst listed company 
Chief Execu � ve role. Given Steve’s performance in the role and following discussions with major shareholders, the Commi � ee felt 
it appropriate to now re-posi � on his salary closer to the appropriate level for the role in line with our policy. While the Commi � ee 
originally considered phasing the increase over � me in line with best prac � ce, it became clear during the consulta � on exercise that 
a number of major investors were comfortable with a one-o ﬀ  adjustment. Accordingly, no � ng the con � nued strong performance of 
the individual and the Group and the very posi � ve feedback from shareholders, the Commi � ee awarded a one-o ﬀ  salary increase to 
£390,000 e ﬀ ec � ve from 1 October 2015.
Following a review of individual and Group performance, Charles Hindson received a 5% salary increase (also e ﬀ ec � ve from 1 
October 2015). This compares with an average increase across the workforce of 2.5%, with actual increases ranging from 0% to 5% 
depending on individual performance. 
The salaries as at 1 April 2016 are therefore:
• Group CEO – £390,000 
• Group Finance Director – £263,682
Base salaries will be reviewed in line with the rest of the Group on 1 October 2016. The increases are expected to be within the 
normal workforce range.

Chairman Share Incen ve Plan 
An award of nil cost op ons was made on 22 July 2013 to Neil Johnson. The award will vest on 22 July 2016 subject to the extent 
which two performance condi ons, share price and total shareholder return (TSR), are met. There is also a shareholding requirement 
of 120,000 shares during the performance period.  001

The face value of the awards (at maximum ves ng) has been calculated using 253.92 pence, being the average closing share price 
over the three days prior to the date of grant. 50% of both awards are based on the Company’s TSR performance rela ve to the TSR 
of the cons tuents of the FTSE Small Cap Index. The other 50% of the awards are based on the Group’s basic adjusted earnings per 
share (EPS) growth. TSR performance is measured over three years from the date of grant and EPS performance is measured over the 
three  nancial years ending 31 March 2018. The performance targets for the rela ve TSR and EPS growth condi ons are the same as 
for the 2014 LTIP awards, as detailed above. 
(E) 2016 LTIP (awards to be made during the year ending 31 March 2017) 
It is intended that LTIP awards will be made in June 2016 whereby the Execu ve Directors will receive nil price op ons based on 100% 
of salary for ‘normal’ awards and 25% of salary for an ‘addi onal award’. The awards will vest on the third anniversary of grant to the 
extent the performance targets have been sa s  ed. 
50% of both the normal and the addi onal awards will be based on the Company’s TSR performance rela ve to the TSR of the 
cons tuents of the FTSE Small Cap Index. The other 50% of the awards is based on the Group’s basic adjusted EPS growth. The 
addi onal awards will be subject to more stretching performance targets.
The rela ve TSR condi on will be the same as for the 2014 and 2015 LTIP awards (see above). The adjusted EPS condi on will 
require growth of 5% to 13% per annum growth for the normal awards (for 25% to 100% ves ng) and 13% to 15% per annum for the 
addi onal awards (for 0% to 100% ves ng). This represents a reduc on in the threshold target for the normal awards from 6% to 5% 
per annum as a result of the challenging market and economic condi ons faced by the Company. The stretch target for the normal 
awards and the target range for the addi onal awards are the same those used in prior years.
The performance measures chosen ensure the alignment of senior management’s and shareholders’ interests. The use of an EPS 
target is consistent with best prac ce and rela ve TSR target is considered to be the output measure of success for the delivery of 
the Group’s growth ambi ons.
Deferred Bonus Plan
A deferred bonus arrangement was introduced for the year ended 31 March 2012 whereby, in addi on to earning up to 100% of 
salary as a cash bonus, the Execu ve Directors may, if maximum performance was achieved, earn up to a further 40% of salary in 
shares, deferred for a period of three years (and subject to con nued employment). A bonus of 127.4% was achieved for the year 
ended 31 March 2012 and an award of 27.4% of salary was made to the Group Finance Director, structured as a nil price op on 
earning dividends. No further awards have been made under this plan. The awards vested on 27 June 2015. The share price on the 
date of ves ng was 253.5p giving a gross value of £105,000.
Share Save Scheme (SAYE) 
The Group operates HM Revenue and Customs approved Share Save Scheme for which all employees and Execu ve Directors can 
apply to join if they are UK employees. The Group CEO and Group Finance Director par cipate in the Scheme. 001

Shareholding guideline
Under the Company’s shareholding guidelines, which are operated to further align the interests of the Execu � ve Directors and 
shareholders, Execu � ve Directors are expected to build up over  ve years and retain shares equal in value to at least twice their 
respec � ve basic salaries. Where Execu � ve Directors hold shares above these levels then, with the prior approval of the Chairman, 
they may undertake sales of these excess shares and this will not be viewed adversely. As at 31 March 2016, Steve Blair holds 
119,338 shares, represen � ng 66% of his annual salary. Charles Hindson holds 1,914,052 shares, which is in excess of the shareholding 
guideline. This is based on the share price on 31 March 2016 of 215.0 pence.
Sourcing of shares – Employee Bene  t Trust (EBT) and treasury shares
The Company established the EBT in 2004 as a discre � onary employee bene  t trust, in which all employees of the Group are 
poten � ally bene  ciaries. The Trustee is EES Trustees Interna � onal Limited, a professional o ﬀ shore trustee. The main purpose of the 
EBT is to operate the LTIP and other share op � on schemes following recommenda � ons from the Remunera � on Commi � ee or Board. 
Shareholder approval has been given to allow the Trustee to hold no more than 5 per cent of the issued ordinary share capital of 
the Company, and as at 31 March 2016 the percentage was 0.21% (2015: 0.36%). 328,490 shares from the EBT having been u � lised 
during the year to sa � sfy LTIP awards that vested. In addi � on to the shares held by the EBT, as at 31 March 2016, the Company held 
in treasury 1,851,091 (2015: 351,037) of its own shares. This holding represents 0.84% (2015: 0.16%) of the issued share capital of 
the Company. 1,500,000 shares were purchased during the year (2015: £nil). No treasury shares were issued during the year (2015: 
1,595,054) to sa � sfy LTIP awards that vested. 001

Share price during the  nancial year
The market price of the ordinary shares at 31 March 2016 was 215.0 pence (2015: 193.0 pence) and the range during the year was 
192.25 pence to 260.75 pence.
Statutory requirements
The remunera on report has been prepared on behalf of the Board by the Remunera on Commi ee.
We adopt the principle of good governance as set out in the UK Corporate Governance Code and comply with the regula ons 
contained in the Schedule 8 of the Large and Medium-sized Companies & Groups (Accounts and Reports) (Amendment) Regula ons 
2013, the Lis ng Rules of the Financial Conduct Authority and the relevant schedules of the Companies Act 2006.
The Companies Act 2006 and the Lis ng Rules require the Company’s auditor to report on the audited informa on in their report 
on page  117 and to state that this sec on has been properly prepared in accordance with these regula ons. The Directors’ Annual 
Report on Remunera on, on pages  54 to  66 is subject to shareholder approval at the AGM on 13 July 2016.
Approval 
This Report was approved by the Remunera on Commi ee and was approved subsequently by the Board of Directors.

1.  Authorisa on of  nancial statements and statement of compliance with IFRS
e2v technologies plc (the Company) is a public limited company incorporated and domiciled in the United Kingdom under the Companies Act 2006. 
The Company’s shares are publicly traded on the London Stock Exchange. The address of the registered o ﬃ  ce is given in the Directors’ Report. The 
nature of the Group’s opera � on and its principal ac � vi � es are set out in the Strategic Report.
The consolidated  nancial statements of the Company for the year ended 31 March 2016 comprise the results of the Company and its subsidiary 
undertakings (together referred to as the Group).
These  nancial statements are presented in Sterling as that is the currency of the primary economic environment in which the Group operates. 
Foreign opera � ons are included in accordance with the policies set out in note 2. All values are rounded to the nearest thousand (£000) unless 
otherwise indicated.
The  nancial statements were approved for issue by the Board on 13  May 2016.
The principal accoun � ng policies adopted by the Group are set out below.
2. Summary of signi cant accoun ng policies
Basis of accoun ng
The  nancial statements have been prepared in accordance with Interna � onal Financial Repor � ng Standards (IFRSs) applied in accordance with the 
Companies Act 2006. The  nancial statements have also been prepared in accordance with IFRSs adopted by the European Union (EU) and therefore 
the consolidated  nancial statements comply with Ar � cle 4 of EU IAS Regula � on. 
The  nancial statements have been prepared on the historical cost basis, except for the revalua � on of certain  nancial and equity instruments. The 
principal accoun � ng policies are set out below and have been applied consistently to all periods presented in these  nancial statements. 
Going concern
The Directors have, at the � me of approving the  nancial statements, a reasonable expecta � on that the Group has adequate resources to con � nue 
in opera � onal existence for the foreseeable future. Thus they con � nue to adopt the going concern basis of accoun � ng in preparing the  nancial 
statements. Further informa � on on the going concern of the Group can be found on page  30 in the viability statement.
Basis of consolida on
The consolidated  nancial statements incorporate the  nancial statements of e2v technologies plc and en � � es controlled by the Company (its 
subsidiaries) made up to 31 March each year. Group subsidiaries are detailed in note 2 to the Company Financial Statements. Control is achieved 
when the Group is exposed, or has rights, to variable returns from its involvement with the investee and has the ability to a ﬀ ect those returns through 
its power over the investee. Speci  cally, the Group controls an investee if, and only if, the Group has:
• Power over the investee (i.e. exis � ng rights that give it the current ability to direct the relevant ac � vi � es of the investee)
• Exposure, or rights, to variable returns from its involvement with the investee
• The ability to use its power over the investee to a ﬀ ect its returns
Generally, there is a presump � on that a majority of vo � ng rights result in control. To support this presump � on and when the Group has less than a 
majority of the vo � ng or similar rights of an investee, the Group considers all relevant facts and circumstances in assessing whether it has power over 
an investee, including:
•  The contractual arrangement with the other vote holders of the investee
•  Rights arising from other contractual arrangements
•  The Group’s vo � ng rights and poten � al vo � ng rights
The Group re-assesses whether or not it controls an investee if facts and circumstances indicate that there are changes to one or more of the 
three elements of control. Consolida � on of a subsidiary begins when the Group obtains control over the subsidiary and ceases when the Group 
loses control of the subsidiary. Assets, liabili � es, income and expenses of a subsidiary acquired or disposed of during the year are included in the 
consolidated  nancial statements from the date the Group gains control un � l the date the Group ceases to control the subsidiary.
Pro  t or loss and each component of other comprehensive income (OCI) are a � ributed to the equity holders of the parent of the Group and to the 
non-controlling interests (if applicable), even if this results in the non-controlling interests having a de  cit balance. When necessary, adjustments 
are made to the  nancial statements of subsidiaries to bring their accoun � ng policies into line with the Group’s accoun � ng policies. All intra-group 
assets and liabili � es, equity, income, expenses and cash  ows rela � ng to transac � ons between members of the Group are eliminated in full on 
consolida � on.
A change in the ownership interest of a subsidiary, without a loss of control, is accounted for as an equity transac � on. If the Group loses control over 
a subsidiary, it derecognises the related assets (including goodwill), liabili � es, non-controlling interest and other components of equity while any 
resultant gain or loss is recognised in pro  t or loss. Any investment retained is recognised at fair value.

2. Summary of signi cant accoun ng policies (con nued)
Business combina ons
For acquisi � ons undertaken a � er 1 April 2010, the acquisi � on of subsidiaries is accounted for using the acquisi � on method of accoun � ng. The cost 
of the acquisi � on is measured as the aggregate of the considera � on transferred, measured at acquisi � on date fair value, and the amount of any 
non-controlling interest in the acquiree. The choice of measurement of non-controlling interest, either at fair value or at the propor � onate share of 
the acquiree’s iden �  able net assets is determined on a transac � on by transac � on basis. Acquisi � on costs incurred are expensed and included in 
administra � ve expenses.
When the Group acquires a business, it assesses the  nancial assets and liabili � es assumed for appropriate classi  ca � on and designa � on in 
accordance with the contractual terms, economic circumstances and per � nent condi � ons as at the acquisi � on date. This includes the separa � on of 
embedded deriva � ves in host contracts by the acquiree.
Goodwill arising on acquisi � on is recognised as an asset and ini � ally measured at cost, being the excess of aggregate of the acquisi � on date fair value 
of the considera � on transferred and the amount recognised for the non-controlling interest over the net iden �  able amounts of the assets acquired 
and the liabili � es assumed in exchange for business combina � on. Assets acquired and liabili � es assumed in transac � ons separate to the business 
combina � ons, such as the se � lement of pre-exis � ng rela � onships or post-acquisi � on remunera � on arrangements, are accounted for separately from 
the business combina � on in accordance with their nature and applicable IFRSs. Iden �  able intangible assets mee � ng either the contractual, legal or 
separability criterion are recognised separately from goodwill. Con � ngent liabili � es represen � ng a present obliga � on are recognised if the acquisi � on 
date fair value can be measured reliably.
If the aggregate of the acquisi � on date fair value of the considera � on transferred and the amounts recognised for the non-controlling interest is 
lower than the fair value of the assets, liabili � es and con � ngent liabili � es and the fair value of any pre-exis � ng interest held in the business acquired, 
the di ﬀ erence is recognised in the income statement.
Where the fair values of the iden �  able net assets and con � ngent liabili � es acquired have been determined provisionally, or where con � ngent 
considera � on is payable, adjustments arsing form their subsequent  nalisa � on are not re  ected in the income statement if they arise within twelve 
months of the acquisi � on date and the adjustments arise from be � er informa � on about condi � ons exis � ng at the acquisi � on date. If con � ngent 
considera � on is classi  ed as equity, it is not remeasured and is accounted for within equity. Otherwise changes are included in the income statement.
Acquisi � ons undertaken prior to 1 April 2010 were accounted for under the purchase method of accoun � ng. However transac � on costs directly 
a � ributable to the acquisi � on formed part of the acquisi � on costs. Furthermore, con � ngent considera � on was recognised if, and only if, the Group 
had a present obliga � on, the economic ou � low was more likely than not and a reliable es � mate was determinable. Subsequent adjustments to the 
con � ngent considera � on were recognised as part of goodwill.
Foreign currency transla on
The individual  nancial statements of each Group company are presented in the currency of the primary economic environment in which it operates 
(its func � onal currency). For the purpose of the consolidated  nancial statements, the results and  nancial posi � on of each Group company are 
retranslated into Sterling, which is the func � onal currency of the Company, and the presenta � on currency for the consolidated  nancial statements.
In preparing the  nancial statements of the individual companies, transac � ons in currencies other than the en � ty’s func � onal currency (foreign 
currencies) are recognised at the rates of exchange prevailing on the dates of the transac � ons. At each balance sheet date, monetary assets and 
liabili � es that are denominated in foreign currencies are retranslated at the rate of exchange ruling at that date. Non-monetary items carried at fair 
value that are denominated in foreign currencies are translated at the rates prevailing at the date when the fair value was determined. Non-monetary 
items that are measured at historical cost in a foreign currency are not retranslated. 
All exchange di ﬀ erences are recognised in the income statement in the period in which they arise except for: exchange di ﬀ erences on transac� ons 
entered into that hedge certain foreign currency risks; and exchange di ﬀ erences on monetary items receivable from or payable to a foreign opera � on 
for which se � lement is neither planned nor likely to occur in the foreseeable future (therefore forming part of the net investment in the foreign 
opera � on), which are recognised ini � ally in other comprehensive income and reclassi  ed from equity to pro  t or loss on disposal or par � al disposal of 
the net investment. 
On consolida � on, the assets and liabili � es of overseas subsidiary undertakings are translated at the rate of exchange ruling at the balance sheet date. 
Income and expense items are translated at the average exchange rate for the period, unless exchange rates  uctuate signi  cantly during the period, 
in which case the exchange rates at the date of transac � ons are used. The exchange di ﬀ erences arising, if any, are recognised in other comprehensive 
income and accumulated in equity, within the foreign currency transla � on reserve. On disposal of a foreign opera � on, all of the accumulated 
exchange di ﬀ erences in respect of that opera � on a � ributable to the Group are reclassi  ed to the income statement. 
Goodwill and fair value adjustments arising on the acquisi � on of a foreign en � ty are treated as assets and liabili � es of the foreign en � ty and translated 
at the rate of exchange ruling at the balance sheet date.

2. Summary of signi cant accoun ng policies (con nued)
Property, plant and equipment
Freehold buildings, plant and equipment held for use in the produc � on or supply of goods or services, or for administra � ve purposes are stated at 
cost less accumulated deprecia � on and any impairment in value.
Assets under construc � on for produc � on or administra � ve purposes are carried at cost, less any recognised impairment loss. Cost includes 
professional fees and, for qualifying assets, borrowing costs capitalised in accordance with the Group’s accoun � ng policy. Deprecia � on on these 
assets commences when the assets are available for use.
Freehold land is not depreciated and is held at historical cost.
Deprecia � on is recognised so as to write-o ﬀ  the cost of assets (other than land and assets under construc � on) less their residual values on a straight-
line basis over the es � mated useful life, as follows:
Freehold buildings   25 to 50 years
Leasehold improvements  over the remaining lease term
Plant and equipment   3 to 10 years
O ﬃ  ce equipment,  xtures and  �  ngs 3 to 10 years
The carrying values are reviewed for impairment when events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable. If any 
such indica � on exists and where the carrying values exceed the es � mated recoverable amount, the assets or cash genera � ng units are wri � en down 
to their recoverable amount. The recoverable amount of plant and equipment is the greater of net selling price and value in use. In assessing value 
in use, the es � mated future cash  ows are discounted to their present value using a pre-tax discount rate that re  ects current market assessments 
of the � me value of money and the risks speci  c to the asset. For an asset that does not generate largely independent cash in  ows, the recoverable 
amount is determined for the cash genera � ng unit to which the asset belongs. Impairment losses are recognised in the income statement in the 
administra � ve expenses line item. Where an impairment loss subsequently reverses, the carrying value of the asset is increased to the revised 
es � mate of its recoverable amount, not to exceed the carrying amount that would have been determined, net of deprecia � on, had no impairment 
loss been recognised for this asset in prior years. A reversal of impairment loss is recognised immediately in the income statement.
An item of property, plant and equipment is derecognised upon disposal or when no future economic bene  ts are expected to arise from the 
con � nued use of the asset. Any gain or loss arising on derecogni � on of the asset (calculated as the di ﬀ erence between the net disposal proceeds and 
the carrying amount of the item) is included in the income statement in the year the item is derecognised.
Goodwill
Goodwill arising on consolida � on represents the excess of the cost of an acquisi � on over the Group’ s interest in the fair value of the iden �  able assets 
and liabili � es of the subsidiary. Goodwill is ini � ally recognised as an asset at cost and is subsequently measured at cost less any accumulated impairment 
losses. Goodwill which is recognised as an asset is reviewed for impairment annually or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances indicate 
that the carrying value may be impaired. Any impairment is recognised immediately in the income statement and is not subsequently reversed. 
For the purpose of impairment tes � ng, goodwill is allocated to each of the Group’s cash genera � ng units expected to bene  t from the synergies 
of the combina � on. Impairment is determined by assessing the recoverable amount of the cash genera � ng unit, to which goodwill relates. If the 
recoverable amount of the cash genera � ng unit is less than the carrying amount, an impairment loss is allocated  rst to reduce the carrying amount 
of any goodwill allocated to the unit and then to other assets of the unit pro-rata on the basis of the carrying amount of each asset in the unit. 
On disposal of a cash genera � ng unit or part of the cash genera � ng unit the a � ributable amount of goodwill is included in the determina � on of the 
pro  t or loss on disposal.
Goodwill arising on acquisi � ons before the date of transi � on to IFRSs has been retained at the previous amounts recorded under UK Generally 
Accepted Accoun � ng Prac � ce (UK GAAP) subject to being tested for impairment at that date. Goodwill wri � en o ﬀ  to reserves under UK GAAP prior to 
1998 has not been reinstated and will not be included in determining any subsequent pro  t or loss on disposal. 
Intangible assets – research and development costs
Expenditure on research ac � vi � es is recognised as an expense in the period in which it is incurred.
An internally generated intangible asset arising from the Group’s development ac � vi � es is capitalised only if all of the following condi � ons are met: 
an asset is created that can be iden �  ed (such as so � ware and new processes); it is probable that the asset created will generate future economic 
bene  ts; and the development cost of the asset can be measured reliably.
Internally generated intangible assets are amor � sed on a straight-line basis over their useful lives, the period of expected future sales, es � mated at 
between three and  ve years. The amor � sa � on is recorded as part of research and development costs in the income statement. Where no internally 
generated intangible asset can be capitalised, development expenditure is recognised as an expense in the period in which it is incurred.
When the asset is not in use, the carrying value of development costs is reviewed for impairment annually or more frequently when an indicator of 
impairment arises during the repor � ng period indica � ng that the carrying value may not be recoverable. 
Gains or losses arising from derecogni � on of an intangible asset are measured as the di ﬀ erence between the net disposal proceeds and the carrying 
amount of the asset and are recognised in the income statement when the asset is derecognised.  001
