Other intangible assets
Intangible assets acquired separately are capitalised at cost and intangible assets acquired from a business acquisi � on are capitalised at fair value as 
at the date of acquisi � on. Following ini � al recogni � on, the cost model is applied to the class of intangible assets. 
Computer so � ware purchased or internally generated for use that is integral to the hardware (because without that so � ware the equipment cannot 
operate) is treated as part of the hardware and capitalised as property, plant and equipment. Other so � ware programmes are treated as intangible 
assets. Intangible assets, excluding development costs and so � ware, created within the business are not capitalised and expenditure is charged to the 
income statement in the period in which the expenditure is incurred. 
Intangible assets are tested for impairment annually either individually or at the cash genera � ng unit level. Useful lives are also examined on an annual 
basis and adjustments, where applicable, are made on a prospec � ve basis. 
The useful lives of these intangible assets are assessed to be either  nite or inde  nite. Where amor � sa � on is charged on assets with  nite lives, it is 
provided so as to write-o ﬀ  the cost of intangible assets on a straight-line basis over the es � mated useful life, as follows:
Patents, trademarks and technology 5 to 10 years
Customer rela � onships and agreements 4 to 10 years
So � ware    2 to 7 years
This expense is recorded in the income statement in administra � ve costs. Assets held under  nance leases are depreciated over the shorter of the 
lease term or their useful economic life. 
Inventories
Inventories are stated at the lower of cost and net realisable value. Cost comprises direct materials and, where applicable, direct labour costs and 
those overheads that have been incurred in bringing the inventories to their present loca � on and condi � on. Cost is calculated using a  rst-in,  rst-out 
method. Net realisable value represents the es � mated selling prices less all es � mated costs of comple � on and costs to be incurred in marke � ng, 
selling and distribu � on.
Provision is made for obsolete, slow-moving or defec � ve items where appropriate. A net increase in provision for the year as a whole is recognised as 
an expense in the year whilst a net reversal of provision for the year as a whole is recognised as a reduc � on in expense. 
Financial assets
All  nancial assets are recognised and derecognised on a trade date where the purchase or sale of a  nancial asset is under a contract whose terms 
require delivery of the  nancial asset within the � meframe established by the market concerned, and are ini � ally measured at fair value, plus 
transac � on costs, except for those  nancial assets classi  ed as fair value through pro  t or loss, which are ini � ally measured at fair value.
Financial assets are classi  ed into the following categories:  nancial assets ‘at fair value through pro  t or loss’ (FVTPL), ‘held-to-maturity’ investments, 
‘available-for-sale’  nancial assets and ‘loans and receivables’ . The classi  ca � on depends on the nature and purpose of the  nancial assets and is 
determined at the � me of recogni � on.
Financial assets, other than those at FVTPL, are assessed for indicators of impairment at each balance sheet date. Financial assets are impaired where 
there is objec � ve evidence that, as a result of one or events that occurred a � er the ini � al recogni � on of the  nancial asset, the es � mated future cash 
 ows of the investment have been a ﬀ ected.
The Group derecognises a  nancial asset only when the contractual rights to the cash  ows from the asset expire, or when it transfers the  nancial 
asset and substan � ally all the risks and rewards of ownership of the asset to another en � ty.
Trade and other receivables
Trade receivables, which generally have 30 to 60 day terms, are recognised and carried at original invoice amount less an allowance for any 
uncollec � ble amounts. An es � mate for doub � ul debts is made when collec � on of the full amount is no longer probable. Bad debts are wri � en o ﬀ  
when iden �  ed.
Cash and cash equivalents
Cash in the balance sheet comprises cash at bank and in hand and short term deposits with an original maturity of three months or less. For the 
purpose of the Consolidated statement of cash  ows, cash and cash equivalents consist of cash as de  ned above.
Non-current assets and disposal groups held for sale
Non-current assets and disposal groups classi  ed as held for sale are measured at the lower of carrying amount and fair value less costs to sell.
Non-current assets are classi  ed as held for sale if their carrying amount will be recovered through a sale transac � on rather than through con � nuing 
use. This condi � on is regarded as met only when the sale is highly probable and the asset or the disposal group is available for immediate sale in its 
present condi � on. Management must be commi � ed to the sale which should be expected to qualify for recogni � on as a completed sale within one 
year from the date of classi  ca � on.
When the Group is commi � ed to the sale plan involving the loss of control of a subsidiary, all of the assets and liabili � es of that subsidiary are classi  ed as 
held for sale when the criteria above are met, regardless of whether the Group will retain a non-controlling interest in its former subsidiary a � er the sale. 001

Financial liabili es
Debt and equity instruments are classi  ed as either  nancial liabili � es or equity in accordance with the substance of the contractual arrangement.
Financial liabili � es are classi  ed as either  nancial liabili � es at FVTPL or other  nancial liabili � es. Financial liabili � es are classi  ed as FVTPL when the 
 nancial liability is either held for trading or it is designated as at FVTPL and are stated at fair value, with any gains or losses arising on remeasurement 
recognised in pro  t or loss. Other  nancial liabili � es are ini � ally measured at fair value, net of transac � on costs.
A  nancial liability is generally derecognised when the contract that gives rise to it is se � led, sold, cancelled or expires. Where an exis � ng  nancial 
liability is replaced by another from the same lender on substan � ally di ﬀ erent terms, or the terms of an exis � ng liability are substan � ally modi  ed, 
such an exchange or modi  ca � on is treated as a derecogni � on of an exis � ng liability and the recogni � on of a new liability.
Borrowings 
All loans and borrowings are ini � ally recognised at cost, being the fair value of the considera � on received net of issue costs associated with the 
borrowing. A � er ini � al recogni � on, interest-bearing loans and borrowings are subsequently measured at amor � sed cost using the e ﬀ ec � ve interest 
method. The e ﬀ ec � ve interest method is a method of calcula � ng the amor � sed cost of a  nancial liability and of alloca � ng interest expense over the 
relevant period. The e ﬀ ec � ve interest rate is the rate that exactly discounts es � mated future cash payments through the expected life of the  nancial 
liability, or, where appropriate, a shorter period, to the net carrying amount on ini � al recogni � on.
Borrowings are classi  ed as current liabili � es unless, at the balance sheet date, the Group has an uncondi � onal right to defer se � lement of the liability 
for at least 12 months a � er the balance sheet date.
Borrowing costs
Borrowing costs directly a � ributable to the acquisi � on, construc � on or produc � on of qualifying assets, which are assets that necessarily take 
a substan � al period of � me to get ready for their intended use or sale, are added to the cost of those assets, un � l such � me as the assets are 
substan � ally ready for their intended use or sale. 
All other borrowing costs are recognised in the income statement using the e ﬀ ec � ve interest method.
Provisions
Provisions are recognised when the Group has a present obliga � on (legal or construc � ve) as a result of a past event, it is probable that the Group will 
be required to se � le that obliga � on and a reliable es � mate can be made of the amount of the obliga � on. 
The amount recognised as a provision is based on the best reliable es � mate of the considera � on required to se � le the present obliga � on at the 
balance sheet date, taking into account the risks and uncertain � es surrounding the obliga � on and its carrying amount is the present value of those 
cash  ows.
When some or all of the economic bene  ts required to se � le a provision are expected to be recovered from a third party, a receivable is recognised 
as an asset if it is virtually certain that reimbursement will be received and that the amount of the receivable can be measured reliably.
Present obliga � ons arising under onerous contracts are recognised and measured as provisions. An onerous contract is considered to exist where the 
Group has a contract under which the unavoidable costs of mee � ng the obliga � ons under the contract exceed the economic bene  ts expected to be 
received under it.
Pensions, other post-employment and other employment bene  ts
The Group operates de  ned contribu � on pension schemes which require contribu � ons to be made to a separately administered fund. Payments 
to de  ned contribu � on pension schemes are charged as an expense as they fall due. Payments made to a state-managed pension are dealt with as 
payments to de  ned contribu � on schemes where the Group’s obliga � ons under the schemes are equivalent to those arising in a de  ned contribu � on 
re � rement bene  t scheme.
The Group operates unfunded de  ned bene  t plans in France providing termina � on payments (post-employment bene  t) to employees upon 
re � rement and long service awards paid when the employee reaches certain lengths of service (other employment bene  t). The cost of providing 
bene  ts is determined with actuarial valua � ons being carried out on each balance sheet date. Past service cost is recognised immediately. Actuarial 
gains and losses are recognised in full in the period in which they occur. Those related to the termina � on bene  ts are recognised outside the income 
statement and are presented in other comprehensive income, whilst those related to the long service award are recognised in the income statement. 
When a se � lement or curtailment occurs, the obliga � on and related plan assets are re-measured using current actuarial assump � ons and the 
resultant gain or loss is recognised in the income statement during the period in which the se � lement or curtailment occurs. 001

Share based payment transac ons

Leases
Leases are classi  ed as  nance leases whenever the terms of the lease transfer substan � ally all the risks and rewards of ownership to the lessee. 
Finance lease assets are capitalised at the commencement of the lease term at the lower of the present value of the minimum lease payments or the

Leases are subsequently measured at amor � sed cost using the e ﬀ ec � ve interest method.
All other leases are classi  ed as opera � ng leases. Rental payments under opera � ng leases are charged to the income statement on a straight-line

In the event that lease incen � ves are received to enter into opera � ng leases, such incen � ves are recognised as a liability. The aggregate bene  t of 
incen � ves is recognised as a reduc � on of rental expense on a straight-line basis, except where another systema � c basis is more representa � ve of the 
� me pa � ern in which economic bene  ts from the leased assets are consumed.
Revenue
Revenue is measured at the fair value of the considera � on received or receivable and represents amounts receivable for goods and services provided 
in the normal course of business, net of discounts, VAT and other sales related taxes.
Revenue from the sale of standard products is recognised when all the following condi � ons are sa � s  ed:
•  the Group has transferred to the buyer the signi  cant risks and rewards of ownership of the goods;
•  the Group retains neither con� nuing managerial involvement to the degree usually associated with ownership nor e ﬀ ec � ve control over 
the goods sold;
•  the amount of revenue can be measured reliably;
•  it is probable that the economic bene  ts associated with the transac � on will  ow to the en � ty; and
•  the costs incurred or to be incurred in respect of the transac � on can be measured reliably.

project. The stage of comple � on is determined either by reference to the comple � on of a physical propor � on of the work, dependent upon the 
nature of the underlying project, or by reference to the propor � on that costs incurred for work performed to date bear to the es � mated total project 
costs. Revenues derived from varia � ons on projects are recognised only when they have been accepted by the customer. Full provision is made for 
losses on projects in the period in which they are  rst foreseen.

economic bene  ts will  ow to the Group and the amount of revenue can be measured reliably. Royal � es determined on a � me basis are recognised

Shareholder Informa � on Str a t egic R e port Governance Financials
77
 2. Summary of signi cant accoun ng policies (con nued)
Revenue (con nued)
Finance revenue is recognised when it is probable that the economic bene  ts will  ow to the Group and the amount of income can be measured 
reliably. Finance revenue income is accrued on a � me basis, by reference to the principal outstanding and at the e ﬀ ec � ve interest rate applicable, 
which is the rate that exactly discounts the es � mated future cash receipts through the expected life of the  nancial asset to that asset’s net carrying 
amount on ini � al recogni � on. 
Government grants
Government grants are not recognised un � l there is reasonable assurance that the Group will comply with the condi � ons a � aching to them and 
that the grants will be received. Government grants for research programmes are recognised as revenue over the periods necessary to match them 
with the related costs incurred, and in the income statement are deducted from the related costs. Government grants related to property, plant and 
equipment are treated as deferred income and released to the income statement over the expected useful lives of the assets concerned.
Taxa on
The tax expense represents the sum of the tax currently payable and deferred tax. Income tax is charged or credited to other comprehensive income 
if it relates to items that are charged or credited to other comprehensive income. Similarly, income tax is charged or credited directly to equity if it 
relates to items that are charged or credited  directly to equity. Otherwise income tax is recognised in the income statement.
Current tax
The tax currently payable is based on the taxable pro  t for the year. Taxable pro  t di ﬀ ers from net pro  t as reported in the income statement 
because it excludes items of income or expense that are taxable or deduc � ble in other years and it further excludes items of income or expense that 
are never taxable or deduc � ble. The Group’s liability for current tax is calculated using tax rates that have been enacted or substan � vely enacted by 
the balance sheet date.
Deferred tax
Deferred tax is the tax expected to be payable or recoverable on di ﬀ erences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabili � es in the  nancial 
statements and the corresponding tax bases used in the computa � on of taxable pro  t, and is accounted for using the balance sheet liability method. 
Deferred tax liabili � es are generally recognised for all taxable temporary di ﬀ erences and deferred tax assets are recognised to the extent that it 
is probable that the taxable pro  ts will be available against which deduc � ble temporary di ﬀ erences can be u � lised. Such assets and liabili � es are 
not recognised if the temporary di ﬀ erences arising from the ini � al recogni � on of goodwill or from the ini � al recogni � on (other than in a business 
combina � on) of other assets and liabili � es in a transac � on that a ﬀ ects neither the taxable pro  t nor the accoun � ng pro  t.
Deferred tax liabili � es are recognised for taxable temporary di ﬀ erences arising on investments in subsidiaries except where the Group is able to 
control the reversal of the temporary di ﬀ erence and it is probable that the temporary di ﬀ erence will not reverse in the foreseeable future.
The carrying amount of deferred tax assets is reviewed at each balance sheet date and reduced to the extent it is no longer probable that su ﬃ  cient 
taxable pro  ts will be available to allow all or part of the asset to be recovered.
Deferred tax is measured on an undiscounted basis and is calculated at the tax rates that are expected to apply in the period when the liability is 
se � led or the asset is realised. Deferred tax assets and liabili � es are o ﬀ set when there is a legally enforceable right to set o ﬀ  current tax assets against 
current tax liabili � es and when they relate to income taxes levied by the same taxa � on authority and the Group intends to se � le its current tax assets 
and liabili � es on a net basis.
Deriva ve  nancial instruments and hedging
The Group enters into a variety of deriva � ve  nancial instruments to manage its exposure to interest rate and foreign exchange rate risk, including 
foreign exchange forward contracts and interest rate swaps. Further details of deriva � ve  nancial instruments are disclosed in notes 31 and 32.
Deriva � ve  nancial instruments are ini � ally recognised at fair value on the date on which a deriva � ve contract is entered into and are subsequently 
remeasured to their fair value at each balance sheet date. The resul � ng gain or loss is recognised in the income statement immediately unless the 
deriva � ve is designated and e ﬀ ec � ve as a hedging instrument, in which event the � ming of the recogni � on in the income statement depends on the 
nature of the hedge rela � onship. The Group designates certain deriva � ves as either hedges of the fair value of recognised assets or liabili � es or  rm 
commitments (fair value hedges), hedges of highly probably forecast transac � ons or hedges of foreign currency risk of  rm commitments (cash  ow 
hedges), or hedges of net investments in foreign opera � ons.
No deriva � ve  nancial instruments have been designated as a fair value or cash  ow hedge during the current or prior  nancial year.
A deriva � ve with a posi � ve fair value is presented as a  nancial asset whereas a deriva � ve with a nega � ve fair value is presented as a  nancial liability. 
A deriva � ve is presented as a non-current asset or a non-current liability if the remaining maturity of the instrument is more than 12 months and it is 
not expected to be realised or se � led within 12 months. Other deriva � ves are presented as current assets or current liabili � es.
The Group uses foreign currency borrowings to hedge its investment in currency investments and classi  es the hedging rela � onship as a net 
investment hedge. To the extent that the hedge is e ﬀ ec � ve, changes in the fair value of the hedging instrument are recognised in other comprehensive

Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements (con � nued)
Year ended 31 March 2016
 2. Summary of signi cant accoun ng policies (con nued)
Equity instruments
An equity instrument is any contract that evidences a residual interest in the assets of the en � ty a � er deduc � ng its liabili � es. Equity instruments 
issued by the Group are recognised as the proceeds received, net of direct issue costs.
 Dividend d istribu on
Dividends to holders of equity instruments declared a � er the balance sheet date are not recognised as a liability as at the balance sheet date. Final 
dividend distribu � ons to the Company’s shareholders are recognised in the  nancial statements in the period in which they are approved by the 
Company’s shareholders. Interim dividends are recognised when paid. 
Own shares reserve
e2v technologies plc shares held by the Employee Bene  t Trust and the Company are classi  ed in shareholders’ equity as own shares and are 
recognised at cost. Considera � on received for the sale of such shares is also recognised in equity, with any di ﬀ erence between the proceeds from 
sale and the original cost being taken to retained earnings. No gain or loss is recognised in the income statement or the statement of comprehensive 
income on the purchase, sale, issue or cancella � on of equity shares.
Cri cal accoun ng judgements and key sources of es ma on uncertainty
In the applica � on of the Group’s accoun � ng policies, management must make judgements, es � mates and assump � ons concerning the carrying 
amounts of assets and liabili � es that are not readily apparent from other sources. The es � mates and associated assump � ons are based upon factors 
such as historical experience and other factors that are considered to be relevant. Actual results may di ﬀ er from these es � mates.
The es � mates and underlying assump � ons are reviewed on an ongoing basis. Revisions to accoun � ng es � mates are recognised in the period in which 
the es � mate is revised if the revision a ﬀ ects only that period, or in the period of the revision and future periods if the revision a ﬀ ects both current and 
future periods.
The following are the cri � cal judgements and key sources of es � ma � on uncertainty that the Directors have made in the process of applying the 
Group’s accoun � ng policies and have the most signi  cant e ﬀ ect on the amounts recognised in the consolidated  nancial statements: accoun � ng 
for acquisi � ons (fair valua � on of intangible assets, net assets acquired and con � ngent considera � on payable) (note 13); subsequent impairment of 
goodwill and other intangible assets arising on acquisi � on (note 16); the measurement of long term contract balances as included in work-in-progress 
(note 17) and provisions (note 23), with regard to the stage of comple � on and the total costs to complete; and the measurement of inventory 
provisions, especially with regard to the Group’s inventory holdings for its obsolescence management business and the last � me build programmes 
undertaken in Grenoble ahead of the closure of its front end fabrica � on plant in 2011 (note 17). Other areas of es � ma � on uncertainty include: the 
measurement of product warranty provisions, with regard to the es � ma � on of the level of returns (note 23); the measurement of de  ned bene  t 
liabili � es (note 29); and the measurement and recogni � on of tax liabili � es and deferred tax assets (note 24).
Adjusted pro  t measures
In order to provide a more relevant presenta � on of the Group’s underlying performance, pro  t for each  nancial year has been analysed between:
a) Trading results before speci  c items; and 
b )  T h e e ﬀ ect of speci  c items. Speci  c items are material items of income and expense which, in the opinion of the Directors, because of the 
nature or infrequency of the events giving rise to them, merit separate presenta � on to allow a be � er understanding of the elements of the 
Group’s underlying performance for the  nancial year and are presented on the face of the income statement to facilitate comparisons with 
prior periods and assessments of trends in  nancial performance.
  Sp eci  c opera � ng items may include: business improvement programme expenses; last � me build inventory provisions; gains and losses on 
sale of property; acquisi � on costs; impairments and fair value gains and losses on foreign exchange contracts; all opera � ng items a � ributable 
to terminated or disposed opera � ons and opera � ons held for sale where there is a contractual agreement to sell; and amor � sa � on of 
acquired intangible assets, including impairment.
  Sp eci  c  nance items may include: fair value gains and losses arising on interest rate swaps; realised exchange di ﬀ erences on the re-
denomina � on of borrowings; and write-o ﬀ  of debt issue costs.
 Speci  c tax items include the tax e ﬀ ect on speci  c opera � ng items and speci  c  nance items.

4. Segment informa on
The Group is organised into three opera � ng divisions, which are organised and managed separately based on the key products that they provide. 
Each is treated as an opera � ng segment and a reportable segment in accordance with IFRS 8, ‘Opera � ng Segments’ . 
The opera � ng and reportable segments are: 
•  Imaging providing high quality imaging sensors, cameras and sub-systems which deliver higher performance for our customers across a 
range of applica � ons in the automa � on, healthcare, discovery and environment markets.
•  RF Power producing components and sub-systems that deliver high performance and high reliability radio frequency power genera � on 
for healthcare, industrial and defence applica � ons.
•  Semiconductors providing high reliability semiconductors that meet the demanding speci  ca � ons of our customers. Our design capability 
is  enabling us to partner with customers and move up the value chain by providing mul � -chip modules and boards.
A more detailed descrip � on for each segment is included with the ‘Our value proposi � on - what we do and our key drivers’ sec � ons of the Business 
Review in the Strategic Report.

arising from the corporate management of the Group along with treasury related ac � vi � es.

Acquisi � on related costs
As detailed in note 13, the Group completed the acquisi � on of SP Devices in January 2016 and in connec � on with this incurred one-o ﬀ  transac � on 
costs of £232,000 (2015: £446,000 in connec � on with acquisi � on of AnaFocus). Exchange losses of £199,000 (2015: gains £231,000) have been 
recorded rela � ng to the outstanding con � ngent considera � on for both SP Devices and AnaFocus. Where payments in connec � on with the acquisi � on 
are dependent upon future employment, they are treated as a cost of con � nuing employment, costs of £393,000 (2015: £544,000) have been 
recorded in rela � on to AnaFocus. No such costs arise from the acquisi � on of SP Devices.
Business improvement programme expenses, net
During the year the Group has reposi � oned its regional teams in US and Asia so that they too are aligned with the divisions and has also reorganised 
RF’s defence business into three dis � nct units. Costs of £1,205,000 have been recorded principally related to sta ﬀ  costs and which include £214,000 
to establish a new facility in Lincoln for the Microwave business unit. Project Sunrise, the reorganisa � on of the footprint at the Chelmsford facility, 
con � nues with costs of £441,000 (2015: £686,000) incurred in the period.
In the year ended 31 March 2015, an announcement to cease manufacturing in Beijing, China during the  rst half of the following  nancial year 
was made prior to 31 March 2015, together with the commencement of a consulta � on process regarding the planned closure of the sales o ﬃ  ce in 
Bievres, France. During the current year these work programmes have progressed and a credit of £269,000 recorded, principally as an onerous lease 
provision is no longer required.
During the year ended 31 March 2015, the Group restructured the Group’s central opera � ons, RF Power and Imaging teams and a charge of 
£3,429,000 was recorded in respect of these ac � vi � es and those in Bievres and China, principally related to sta ﬀ  and onerous lease costs. 
Foreign currency (gains)/ losses arising from fair value adjustment 
The Group, in part, hedges its exposure to foreign currency risks through the use of forward exchange contracts. The changes in the fair value of 
the instruments are recorded as speci  c items in the income statement. Fluctua � ons in the exchange rates have resulted in a net fair value gain of 
£618,000 (2015: loss £1,873,000).
Disposal of businesses
On 8 October 2015 the Group sold the trade and assets of the thermal imaging business. The net proceeds on this transac � on were £2,919,000. The 
assets disposed comprised: developments costs (£95,000), property, plant and equipment (£248,000) and inventories (£1,494,000) such that a gain 
on sale of £1,082,000 has been recognised . Deferred considera � on rela � ng to the sale of the Group’s RF Satcom business became receivable in the 
year and a further gain of £50,000 has been recognised. A gain of £100,000 was recognised in the year ended 31 March 2015 in connec � on with this 
same business on the expira � on of product warran � es.
Pro  t on sale of proper � es
In the year ended 31 March 2010, the Group sold its former Lincoln site. The contract included the provision for a further payment dependent upon 
the square footage of the new proper � es built. An amount of £284,000 has been agreed with the developer. 001

 11. Earnings per share
Basic earnings per share is calculated by dividing net pro  t for the year a � ributable to ordinary equity holders of the parent by the weighted average 
number of ordinary shares outstanding during the year. Diluted earnings per share is calculated by dividing the net pro  t for the year a � ributable to 
ordinary shareholders by the weighted average number of ordinary shares outstanding during the year adjusted for the e ﬀ ects of dilu � ve op � ons. 
Adjusted earnings per share is calculated on the basis of net pro  t for the year before speci  c items. In the Directors’ judgement adjusted earnings 
per share is considered to more appropriately re  ect the underlying performance of the business year on year.
The following re  ects the net pro  t and share data used in the basic and diluted earnings per share computa � ons:
      2016 2015

13. Business combina ons
On 22 January 2016, the Group acquired 100% of the share capital of Signal Processing Devices Sweden AB (SP Devices), a Linköping based company 
specialising in the design and development of high performance analogue-to-digital processing technology. The business brings proven patented 
technology in so � ware and board level sub-systems and services, which compliments and enhances e2v’s exis � ng broadband data converter 
business. The acquisi � on has been accounted for using the acquisi � on method. The consolidated  nancial statements include the results of SP 
Devices for the period from the acquisi � on date, reported within the Semiconductors segment (note 4). 001

projec � ons are based on  nancial budgets and models from the Strategy Review, both of which are approved by the Board. The key assump � ons 
used in the valua � ons are:
Opera ng margins – the budgeted margin is used for the coming year, which is then adjusted if required for further years for any expected changes 
due to sales mix or e ﬃ  ciency improvements. 
Discount rates – discount rates re  ect the Directors’ es � mate of the return on capital employed required in every CGU. This is the benchmark used 
by the Group to assess opera � ng performance and to evaluate future capital investment proposals. A 15% (2015: 15%) pre-tax discount rate, adjusted 
for speci  c risk where appropriate, is considered appropriate for the purpose of impairment reviews as it is consistent with the rates used in all 
investment appraisals and is considered to be a conserva � ve es � mate of the return expected by market par � cipants.
Growth rates – have been considered separately for every CGU and are based on  nancial budgets and the Strategy Review. A � er  ve years, a long 
term growth rate of 2.5% (2015: 2.5%) has been u � lised.

Total non-current trade and other payables      2,057 1,091

Trade payables and accruals principally comprise amounts outstanding for trade purchases and ongoing costs. Trade payables and other payables are 
non-interest bearing and are normally se led on 60 day terms or within six months, respec vely. Interest payable is se led monthly, quarterly or half-
yearly throughout the year depending upon the draw down periods under the revolving credit facili es.
Included in accruals and deferred income is the con ngent considera on payable to certain former shareholders of AnaFocus and SP Devices (see 
note 13).
The Directors consider that the carrying amount of trade payables approximates their fair value.

The other principal features of the Group’s borrowings are as follows:
Bank debt
On 29 July 2014, the Group entered into a new revolving credit facility which expires on 28 July 2018, and which is denominated in Sterling 
(£62,500,000), US dollars ($40,000,000) and Euros (€5,000,000). At 31 March 2016 exchange rates, the total facility is £94,268,000 (2015: 
£93,176,000). Provided covenants con nue to be met, the draw down under the revolving credit facility is at the discre on of the Group and 
consequently the loan is treated as non-current. As at 31 March 2016, £36,234,000 (2015: £22,500,000) was drawn down under this facility.
The revolving credit facility is repaid and re-drawn at periodic intervals ranging from one to six months, with the interest rate set at each draw down 
date. Interest is set by reference to LIBOR plus a margin which is determined based on the level of the reported leverage covenant (de  ned as net 
borrowings: earnings before interest, tax, deprecia on and amor sa on).
As at 31 March 2016, the Group had available £58,034,000 (2015: £70,676,000) of un-drawn commi ed borrowing facili es in respect of which all 
condi ons precedent had been met.
As at 31 March 2016, unamor sed debt issue costs were £277 ,000 (2015: £547 ,000). As at 31 March 2016 and at 31 March 2015, the bank loans were 
unsecured.  001

Other loans
Prior to acquisi on, AnaFocus received a number of interest-free or low interest loans from a number of bodies in Spain to support its research and 
development ac vi es. The loans are repayable by instalments through to October 2025. These loans were fair valued on acquisi on, using prevailing 
interest rates for equivalent loans of 5%. This prevailing rate remains appropriate as at 31 March 2016, and therefore the carrying value of £2,356,000 
approximates the fair value.

Onerous project losses
A provision is recognised for expected losses on projects in progress at the balance sheet date. It is expected that the losses will be incurred in the 
next two  nancial years.
Employment related
A restructuring provision is recognised when the Group has developed a detailed formal plan for the restructuring and has raised a valid expecta � on 
in those a ﬀ ected that it will carry out the restructuring by star � ng to implement the plan or announcing its main features to those a ﬀ ected by it. The 
measurement of a restructuring provision includes only the direct expenditures arising from the restructuring, which are those amounts that are both 
necessarily entailed by the restructuring and not associated with the ongoing ac � vi � es of the en � ty. All payments associated with the programme are 
expected to be incurred over the period to March 2017 .

made for any expected costs and liabili � es in rela � on to these proceedings where appropriate, though there can be no guarantee that such provisions 
(which may be subject to poten � ally material revision from � me to � me) will accurately predict the actual costs and liabili � es that may be incurred.
Product warranty
A provision is recognised for expected warranty claims on products sold that are within their warranty period at the end of the year under local sale of 
goods legisla � on or contract terms. The warranty period can be date or hours usage based. It is expected that these costs will be incurred in the next 
two  nancial years. Assump � ons used to calculate the provision for warran � es were based on relevant sales levels and current informa � on available 
about warranty claims and represent the Directors’ best es � mate of the expenditure required to se � le the Group’s obliga � on.

The UK government, with e ﬀ ect from 1 April 2015, reduced the main rate of UK corpora � on tax from 21% to 20%. In addi � on, the Finance Bill 2016, 
which was substan � vely enacted on 26 October 2015, will reduce the UK corpora � on tax rate to 19% from 1 April 2017 and to 18% from 1 April 
2020. UK deferred tax balances as at 31 March 2016 have been calculated based on the reduced corpora � on tax rate of 20%, 19% and 18% being 
the relevant tax rate that is expected to apply to the period when the asset is realised or the liability is se � led. The Spanish government, for  nancial 
periods beginning during 2015, reduced the main rate of Spanish corpora � on tax rate from 30% to 28%, and for  nancial periods beginning during 
2016, reduced the rate further to 25%. Spanish deferred tax balances as at 31 March 2016 have been calculated based on the Spanish corpora � on tax 
rate of 25%, the rate expected to apply to the period when the asset is realised or the liability is se � led.
There are no income tax consequences for the Company a � aching to the payment of dividends to its shareholders.
Management have reviewed the situa � on for those jurisdic � ons where deferred assets arise and have determined, based on current forecasts 
prepared by management, that these assets can be recovered through future taxable pro  ts within a reasonable � me horizon.
At the balance sheet date, the Group has unused tax losses of £6.2 million (2015: £5.0 million) available for o ﬀ set against future pro  ts. A deferred tax 
asset of £1,458 ,000 has been recognised in respect of these losses, which expire between 2026 and 2032.
As at 31 March 2016, the aggregate amount of undistributed earnings of overseas subsidiaries for which deferred tax liabili � es have not been 
recognised is approximately £13 7 million (2015: £113 million). No liability has been recognised in respect of these di ﬀ erences because the Group 
is in the posi � on to control the � ming of the reversal of the temporary di ﬀ erences and it is probable that such di ﬀ erences will not reverse in the 
foreseeable future. It is likely that the majority of the overseas earnings would qualify for the UK dividend exemp � on. 001

Shareholder Informa � on Str a t egic R e port Governance Financials
26. Reserves
Nature and purpose of reserves
Share premium
Generally, addi � ons to this reserve are made when shares are issued, for cash or otherwise, by the Company for amounts in excess of their nominal 
value. This reserve can be u � lised to issue fully paid bonus shares and  to write-o ﬀ  any issue costs .
Merger reserve
The excess of the net proceeds over the nominal value of the share capital issued during the rights issue and placement in 2010 was recognised to the 
merger reserve. The Directors believe this reserve is currently distributable.
Own shares reserve
The own share reserve records movements in e2v technologies plc’s shares held by the EBT or the Company.
 C ap i t al r e d e m p on reserve
The capital redemp � on reserve is used to record reserve transfers required on the redemp � on of shares. This reserve is not distributable.
Foreign currency transla on reserve
The foreign currency transla � on reserve is used to record exchange di ﬀ erences arising from the transla � on of the  nancial statements of foreign 
subsidiaries. It is also used to record the net investments hedged in these subsidiaries. 
27. Commitments and con ngencies
Opera ng lease commitments – Group as lessee
The Group has entered into commercial leases on certain proper � es, motor vehicles and items of machinery where it is not in the best interest of the 
Group to purchase these assets. Renewals are at the op � on of the speci  c en � ty that holds the lease. There are no restric � ons placed upon the lessee 
by entering into these leases.
Future minimum rentals payable under non-cancellable opera � ng leases as at 31 March are as follows:
      2016 2015
      £000 £000

Capital commitments
At 31 March 2016, the Group has commitments of £1,277 ,000 (2015: £3,835,000) principally rela � ng to the acquisi � on of new plant and equipment.
Con ngent liabili es
The Company and its subsidiaries may be par � es to legal proceedings and claims which arise in the ordinary course of business, and can be material 
in value. Appropriate provision has been made in these accounts where, in the opinion of the Directors, liabili � es are likely to materialise (note 23). 
Furthermore, in the ordinary course of business, the Group may also issue performance and advance payment guarantees. Guarantees are treated as 
con � ngent liabili � es un � l such � me as it becomes probable that a payment will be required under the terms of the guarantee. As at 31 March 2016, 
bank guarantees of £3,406,000 (2015: £3,580,000) are outstanding. 
The Group has received grant assistance from the UK government’s Regional Growth Fund which is condi � onal on certain job targets being achieved 
in future years. The Directors are of the opinion that the risk of repayment of the grants is not signi  cant and consequently no liability is recorded for 
the repayment of such grants.
28. Equity se led share based payments
The Group operates three share based award schemes as detailed below. The share based payment expense charged to the income statement as an 
administra � ve cost for the year ended 31 March 2016 was £1,200,000 (2015: £875,000).
Long Term Incen ve Plan (LTIP)
For those awards made during the year ended 31 March 2016, awards vest on the third anniversary of the date of the award, subject to performance 
targets being met. For the ‘normal’ awards, 50% of the awards are subject to a performance condi � on based on the Group’s adjusted earnings per 
share (Adjusted EPS) and the remaining 50% of the awards are subject to a performance condi � on which relates the Company’s Total Shareholder 
Return (TSR) performance rela � ve to the TSR for the FTSE Small Cap Index (calculated as an average over the three month period ending on the 
last day of the performance period). Addi � onal awards made to the Group CEO and Group Financial Director also have 50% of the award subject to 
Adjusted EPS and 50% of the award subject to rela � ve TSR performance; however more stretching targets are assigned to these awards compared 
with the ‘normal’ awards. 001

Annual Report & Financial Statements

98
Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements (con nued)
Year ended 31 March 2016
28. Equity se led share based payments (con nued)
Long Term Incen ve Plan (LTIP) (con nued)
For those awards made during the year ended 31 March 2015, awards vest on the third anniversary of the date of the award, subject to performance 
targets being met. For the ‘normal’ awards, 50% of the awards are subject to a performance condi on based on the Group’s adjusted earnings per 
Share (Adjusted EPS) and the remaining 50% of the awards are subject to a performance condi on which relates the Company’s Total Shareholder 
Return (TSR) performance rela ve to the TSR for the FTSE Small Cap Index (calculated as an average over the three month period ending on the 
last day of the performance period). Addi onal awards made to the Group CEO and Group Financial Director also have 50% of the award subject to 
Adjusted EPS and 50% of the award subject to rela ve TSR performance; however more stretching targets are assigned to these awards compared 
with the ‘normal’ awards.
For those awards made during the year ended 31 March 2014, awards vest on either the third or fourth anniversary of the date of the award, subject 
to performance targets being met. For the ‘normal’ awards, 50% of the awards are subject to a performance condi on based on the Company’s 
absolute TSR performance calculated as an average over the three month period ending on the last day of the performance period and the remaining 
50% of the awards are subject to a performance condi on which relates the Company’s TSR performance rela ve to the TSR of a speci  ed list of 
peer group companies. Addi onal awards were made to the Group Financial Director which also have 50% of the award subject to absolute TSR 
performance and 50% of the award subject to rela ve TSR performance; however more stretching targets are assigned to these awards compared 
with the ‘normal’ awards.
All awards under this scheme have a nil exercise price and have no end date by which they must be exercised. The following table provides details of 
awards made under this scheme:
      2016 2015
      No. No.
Outstanding at the beginning of the year      2,774,021 3,980,842
Granted during the year      817,386 1,031,951
Exercised during the year      (328,490) (1,595,054)
Forfeited during the year      (499,325) (643,718)
Outstanding at the end of the year      2,763,592 2,774,021
Shares in rela on to the LTIP will ini ally be issued from those currently held by the EBT or from those held in treasury by the Company. See note 25 
for the number of shares held and for the resul ng balance recorded within reserves.
There were 120,956 op ons exercisable at the balance sheet date (2015: nil).
Deferred Share Awards
A deferred bonus arrangement was introduced for the year ended 31 March 2012, whereby in addi on to earning up to 100% of salary as a cash 
bonus, the Execu ve Directors may, if maximum performance is achieved, earn up to a further 40% of salary in shares, deferred for a period of three 
years (and subject to con nued employment). All awards under this scheme have a nil exercise price and which will normally be exercisable for three 
years following ves ng. The shares issued on ves ng will be adjusted for any dividends declared since the op ons were issued. The following table 
provides details of awards made under this scheme:
      2016 2015
      No. No.
Outstanding at the beginning of the year      41,491 41,491
Dividend      3,864 –
Outstanding at the end of the year      45,355 41,491
These op ons are exercisable as the balance sheet date (2015: nil).
Chairman and Group CEO Share Incen ve Plans
In the normal course of events the award under the Chairman Share Incen ve Plan (Chairman’s Award) will vest on the third anniversary of the grant 
date, subject to the extent to which both a share price and TSR condi on are met, as measured over the three year performance period. The TSR 
condi on relates the Group’s TSR performance to the TSR for the FTSE Small Cap Index. There is also a shareholding requirement of 120,000 shares 
during the performance period. 
Under the Group CEO Share Incen ve Plan there are two awards, a Joining Award and a Matching Award. In the normal course of events, both the 
Joining and Matching Awards will vest on the third anniversary of the grant date. The ves ng of the Joining Award is subject to the Group CEO’s 
con nued employment at that date and a shareholding requirement of 72,338 shares during the ves ng period. The ves ng of the Matching Award is 
subject to the extent which both a share price and TSR condi on are met, as measured over the period to 22 July 2016 (i.e. the same end date to the 
performance period as the Chairman’s Award). The TSR condi on relates the Group’s TSR performance to the TSR for the FTSE Small Cap Index. 001

29. Pensions, other post-employment and other employment bene  ts
De  ned contribu on plans
The Group has de  ned contribu � on plans in the UK and North America, covering substan � ally all of its employees, which require contribu � ons to 
be made to a separately administered fund. The Group contributes to state schemes for Con � nental European ac � vi � es. Such schemes are de  ned 
contribu � on schemes and there is no Group exposure to any scheme liabili � es. The de  ned contribu � on expense charged to the income statement 
during the period was £2,287 ,000 (2015: £2,227 ,000). Contribu � ons of £316,000 (2015: £292,000) were outstanding at the end of the  nancial year 
and have been included in other creditors.
 Other post-employment and other employment bene  ts
In addi � on to the state pension scheme, e2v semiconductors SAS and e2v SAS have arrangements where there are obliga � ons to provide termina � on 
allowances and ‘Medailles du Travail’ (long service awards). These are unfunded arrangements and the actuarial liability has been calculated at 31 
March 2016 by a quali  ed actuary using the unit credit method. The cost of providing these bene  ts is charged to the income statement in the period 
in which those bene  ts have been earned by the employees. Remeasurement gains and losses are recognised in full in the period in which they arise. 
For the termina � on allowance the remeasurement gains and losses are recorded in other comprehensive income whereas for the long service award 
the remeasurement gains and losses are recorded in the income statement. 
The main assump � ons used in determining the liabili � es of the arrangements include the discount rate for discoun � ng scheme liabili � es, the 
expected rate of salary in  a � on, sta ﬀ  turnover rates, re � rement age and future mortality in service assump � ons. For each of these assump � ons, 
there is a range of possible values. Rela � vely small changes in some of these variables can have a signi  cant e ﬀ ect on the level of the total obliga � on.
As at 31 March 2016, a non-current liability of £5,298,000 (2015: £4,893,000) has been recognised with respect to the termina � on allowance and 
long service award arrangements.

Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements (con � nued)
Year ended 31 March 2016
31. Financial risk management objec � ves and policies
The Group’s principal  nancial instruments, other than deriva � ves, comprise bank and other loans,  nance leases and cash. The main purpose of 
these  nancial instruments is to raise  nance for the Group’s opera � ons. The Group has various other  nancial instruments such as trade debtors and 
trade creditors, which arise directly from its opera � ons.
The Group also enters into deriva � ve transac � ons, principally forward currency contracts. The purpose is to manage the currency risks arising from 
the Group’s opera � ons and its sources of  nance.
It is, and has been throughout the year under review, the Group’s policy that no trading in  nancial instruments shall be undertaken.
The main risks arising from the Group’s  nancial instruments are interest rate risk, liquidity risk, foreign currency risk and credit risk. The Board 
reviews and agrees policies for managing each of these risks and they are summarised below. The Group also monitors the market price risk arising 
from all  nancial instruments. The magnitude of this risk that has arisen over the year is discussed in note 32. The Group’s accoun � ng policies in 
rela � on to deriva � ves are set out in note 2.
Interest rate risk 
The Group’s exposure to market risk for changes in interest rates relates primarily to the Group’s debt obliga � ons.
Where term debt exists, it is the Group’s policy to manage its interest cost using a mix of  xed and variable rate debt. To manage this mix in a cost 
e ﬃ  cient manner, the Group will enter into interest rate swaps, in which the Group agrees to exchange, at speci  ed intervals, the di ﬀ erence between 
 xed and variable interest amounts calculated by reference to an agreed upon no � onal principal amount and will draw down por � ons of its revolving 
credit facility for periods of up to six months. At 31 March 2016 and 31 March 2015, the Group did not have any term debt and therefore there were 
no interest rate swaps in place.
Based on the borrowings outstanding at the end of the year and assuming constant exchange rates, it is es � mated that an increase of 1% in interest 
rates on the Group’s borrowings would increase the annual interest payable by £0.3 million (2015: £0.2 million). A 1% increase in interest rates on 
bank deposits is es � mated to increase  nance revenue by less than £0.1 million (2015: less than £0.1 million).
Foreign currency risk 
The Group has opera � ons in the United States, Europe and Asia. As a result the Group’s balance sheet can be a ﬀ ected signi  cantly by movements in 
the US dollar and Euro exchange rates. The Group does not currently hedge this exposure, other than by using foreign currency borrowings, in part, to 
 nance overseas investments.
The Group also has transac � onal currency exposures. Such exposure arises from sales by an opera � ng unit in currencies other than the unit’s 
func � onal currency. Approximately 85% (2015: 85%) of the Group’s sales are outside of the UK and a signi  cant propor � on of these sales are not 
in Sterling and therefore subject to foreign exchange. The Group also incurs opera � onal costs in both US dollars and Euros. The Group manages its 
transac � onal currency exposures centrally by using forward currency contracts to minimise the net currency exposures. It is the Group’s policy to 
enter into forward exchange contracts to cover speci  c foreign currency receipts and payments.
The following table demonstrates the Group’s sensi � vity to a reasonably possible strengthening or weakening in the US dollar and Euro exchange 
rates in rela � on to Sterling with all other variables held constant. The sensi � vity analysis includes only outstanding foreign currency denominated 
monetary items at the balance sheet date. The sensi � vity excludes external loans as exchange gains and losses on retransla � on are not reported 
within pro  t before taxa � on.

Credit risk 
The Group trades only with businesses it considers creditworthy third par � es. It is the Group’ s policy that all customers who wish to trade on credit terms 
are subject to credit veri  ca � on procedures. In addi � on, receivable balances are monitored on an ongoing basis with the result that the Group’ s exposure 
to bad debts is not signi  cant. Trade receivables consist of a large number of customers, spread across diverse industries and geographical areas.
With respect to credit risk arising from  nancial assets of the Group, which comprise trade and other receivables and cash, the Group’s exposure 
to credit risk arises from default of the counterparty, with a maximum exposure equal to the carrying amount of these instruments. There are no 
signi  cant concentra � ons of credit risk within the Group.
Credit risk to  nancial ins � tu � ons is limited by restric � ng the range of counterpar � es to those with high credit ra � ngs.
Liquidity risk 
Liquidity risk is the risk that the Group will not be able to meet its  nancial obliga � ons as they fall due. Liquidity risk is managed by monitoring forecast 
and actual cash  ows and ensuring that su ﬃ  cient commi � ed facili � es are in place to cover possible downside scenarios. 
The Group currently maintains a balance between con � nuity of funding and  exibility through the use of the revolving credit facility. The Group’s 
objec � ve is to maintain a posi � ve cash balance at a level adequate for daily opera � ons with any funds in excess of this used to make repayments 
against the revolving facility agreement.

31. Financial risk management objec ves and policies (con nued)
Liquidity risk (con nued)
The carrying value of interest-bearing loans and borrowings is a er a deduc on for unamor sed debt issue costs of £277 ,000 (2015: £547 ,000). 
Interest payable on loans and borrowings is calculated on an undiscounted basis at borrowing rates applicable at the end of the year.
The maturity analysis for  nance leases and deriva ve  nancial liabili es are detailed in notes 21 and 22, respec vely.
Capital management 
The Group manages its capital to ensure that en  es in the Group will be able to con nue as a going concern whilst maximising the return to 
stakeholders through the op misa on of the debt and equity balance. The Group’s capital comprises shareholders’ funds as detailed in notes 25 and 
26 and net borrowings as detailed above and in note 21. The Group manages its capital structure through maintaining close rela onships with its 
bankers who provide the majority of funds used for opera onal requirements.
As at 31 March 2016, the Company was holding 1,851,091 (2015: 351,037) shares in treasury. During the year the Group purchased 1,500,000 shares 
(2015: nil) in the Company and no treasury shares (2015: 1,595,054) were released to sa sfy LTIP awards that vested. These treasury shares are seen 
as a hedge against those shares which may be required to be transferred to sa sfy op ons under the LTIP , deferred share scheme and the Chairman’s 
and Group CEO’s Share Incen ve Plans as they vest.
The Group is required to maintain covenant ra os in respect of: leverage (de  ned as net borrowings to rolling 12 months earnings before interest, 
tax, deprecia on and amor sa on (including earnings from acquisi ons for a full 12 months on a proforma basis)) and interest cover (de  ned as net 
interest costs to earnings before interest, tax and amor sa on). Breach of these covenants would cons tute events of default under the facili es 
which might result in these payments becoming immediately repayable. The Group has met its covenant ra os for the year ended 31 March 2016 and 
forecasts indicate that the current plan can be managed within the exis ng covenant levels.
Neither the Company nor any of its subsidiaries are subject to externally imposed capital requirements.
The Company intends to con nue its progressive dividend policy, with an interim dividend of 1.6 pence paid during the current year and a proposed 
 nal dividend of 3.8  pence.

Fair value hierarchy
In accordance with IFRS 7 , ‘Financial Instruments: Disclosures’ , the Group classi  es fair value measurement using a fair value hierarchy that re  ects 
the signi  cance of inputs used in making measurements of fair value. The fair value hierarchy has the following levels:
Level 1 quoted prices (unadjusted) in ac ve markets for iden  able assets or liabili es;
Level 2  inputs other than quoted prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly (i.e. prices) or indirectly 
(i.e. derived from prices); and
Level 3 inputs for the asset or liability that are not based on observable market data (unobservable inputs). 001

32. Financial instruments (con nued)
Fair value hierarchy (con nued)
The fair value of forward currency contracts is calculated by management based on external valua ons received from the Group’s bankers and 
is based on forward exchange rates, respec vely. The fair value measurement basis of the instruments is categorised within Level 2. The carrying 
amount of the other  nancial instruments of the Group, i.e. short term trade receivables, payables and provisions that are not included in the above 
table, is a reasonable approxima on of fair value.
 Currency – forward exchange contracts
The Group holds several forward exchange contracts designated to reduce the transac onal exchange risk of US dollar denominated sales to 
customers. The terms of these contracts are as follows:

e2v technologies plc Annual Report and Financial Statements 201 6         
109
Shareholder Informa � on Str a t egic R e port Governance Financials
1 .  A c c o u n ng policies (con nued)
Taxa on
The tax expense represents the sum of the tax currently payable and deferred tax.  Income tax is charged or credited to other comprehensive income 
if it relates to items that are charged or credited to other comprehensive income.  Similarly, income tax is charged or credited directly to equity if it 
relates to items that are charged or  credited directly to equity.  Otherwise income tax is recognised in the pro  t and loss account.
Current tax
The tax currently payable is based on the taxable pro  t for the year.  Taxable pro  t di ﬀ ers from net pro  t as reported in the pro  t and loss account 
because it excludes items of income or expense that are taxable or deduc � ble in other years and it further excludes items of income or expense that 
are never taxable or deduc � ble.  The Company’s liability for current tax is calculated using tax rates that have been enacted or substan � vely enacted 
by the balance sheet date.
Deferred tax
Deferred tax is the tax expected to be payable or recoverable on di ﬀ erences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabili � es in the  nancial 
statements and the corresponding tax bases used in the computa � on of taxable pro  t, and is accounted for using the balance sheet liability method.  
Deferred tax liabili � es are generally recognised for all taxable temporary di ﬀ erences and deferred tax assets are recognised to the extent that it 
is probable that the taxable pro  ts will be available against which deduc � ble temporary di ﬀ erences can be u � lised.  Such assets and liabili � es are 
not recognised if the temporary di ﬀ erences arising from the ini � al recogni � on of goodwill or from the ini � al recogni � on (other than in a business 
combina � on) of other assets and liabili � es in a transac � on that a ﬀ ects neither the taxable pro  t nor the accoun � ng pro  t.
Deferred tax liabili � es are recognised for taxable temporary di ﬀ erences arising on investments in subsidiaries except where the Company is able to 
control the reversal of the temporary di ﬀ erence and it is probable that the temporary di ﬀ erence will not reverse in the foreseeable future.
The carrying amount of deferred tax assets is reviewed at each balance sheet date and reduced to the extent it is no longer probable that su ﬃ  cient 
taxable pro  ts will be available to allow all or part of the asset to be recovered.
Deferred tax is measured on an undiscounted basis and is calculated at the tax rates that are expected to apply in the period when the liability is 
se � led or the asset is realised.  Deferred tax assets and liabili � es are o ﬀ set when there is a legally enforceable right to set o ﬀ  current tax assets against 
current tax liabili � es and when they relate to income taxes levied by the same taxa � on authority and the Company intends to se � le its current tax 
assets and liabili � es on a net basis.
Pensions
The Company contributes to personal pension arrangements for its employees.  The pension cost is the amount of contribu � ons payable in the year.  
Di ﬀ erences between contribu � ons payable in the year and contribu � ons paid are shown either as accruals or prepayments in the balance sheet.
Share based payments
Employees (including Directors) of the Company receive remunera � on in the form of share based transac � ons, whereby employees render services 
in exchange for shares or rights over shares (equity se � led transac � ons).  The cost of equity se � led transac � ons with employees is measured by 
reference to the fair value at the date at which they are granted.  The fair value is determined using a binomial, Monte Carlo or Black-Scholes model, 
as appropriate.  Further details are given in note  28 to the consolidated  nancial statements.  In valuing equity se � led transac � ons, no account is 
taken of any ves � ng condi � ons, other than condi � ons linked to the price of the shares of the Company (market condi � ons).
The cost of equity se � led transac � ons is recognised, together with a corresponding increase in equity, over the period in which the performance 
condi � ons are ful  lled, ending on the date on which the relevant employees become fully en � tled to the award (ves � ng date).  The cumula � ve 
expense recognised for equity se � led transac � ons at each repor � ng date re  ects the extent to which the ves � ng period has expired and 
management’s best es � mate of the number of awards that will ul � mately vest.
The  nancial e ﬀ ect of awards by the Company of op � ons over its equity shares to employees of subsidiary undertakings are recognised by the 
Company in its individual  nancial statements with the Company recording an increase in its investment in subsidiaries and a credit to equity.  
No expense is recognised for awards that do not ul � mately vest, except for awards where ves � ng is condi � onal upon a market condi � on, which are 
treated as ves � ng irrespec � ve of whether or not the market condi � on is sa � s  ed, provided that all other performance condi � ons are sa � s  ed.
Where the terms of an equity se � led award are modi  ed, as a minimum an expense is recognised as if the terms had not been modi  ed.  In addi � on, 
an expense is recognised for any increase in the value of the transac � on as a result of the modi  ca � on, as measured at the date of modi ca � on.
Where an equity se � led award is cancelled, it is treated as if it had vested on the date of cancella � on, and any expense not yet recognised for the 
award is recognised immediately.  If a new award is subs � tuted for the cancelled award, and designated as a replacement award on the date that it is 
granted, the cancelled and new shares are treated as if they were a modi  ca � on of the original award.
Dividend income
Dividend income from subsidiary undertakings is recognised at the point the dividend has been declared.  Dividends declared a � er the balance sheet 
date are not recognised in the pro  t and loss account. 001

 1 . A c c o u n ng policies (con nued)
Financial liabili es and equity
Debt and equity instruments are classi  ed as either  nancial liabili � es or equity in accordance with the substance of the contractual arrangement.  
An equity instrument is any contract that evidences a residual interest in the assets of the en � ty a � er deduc � ng its liabili � es.  Equity instruments 
issued by the Company are recognised as the proceeds received, net of direct issue costs.
A  nancial liability is generally derecognised when the contract that gives rise to it is se � led, sold, cancelled or expires.  Where an exis � ng  nancial 
liability is replaced by another from the same lender on substan � ally di ﬀ erent terms, or the terms of an exis � ng liability are substan � ally modi  ed, 
such an exchange or modi  ca � on is treated as a derecogni � on of the original liability and the recogni � on of a new liability.
Bank borrowings
Interest-bearing bank loans are recorded at the proceeds received, net of direct issue costs.  A � er ini � al recogni � on, interest-bearing bank loans are 
subsequently measured at amor � sed cost using the e ﬀ ec � ve interest method.
Dividend distribu on
Dividends to holders of equity instruments declared a � er the balance sheet date are not recognised as a liability as at the balance sheet date.  Final 
dividend distribu � ons to the Company’s shareholders are recognised in the  nancial statements in the period in which they are approved by the 
Company’s shareholders.  Interim dividends are recognised when paid. 
Own shares
Shares in e2v technologies plc held by the Company or the Employee Bene  t Trust (EBT) are stated at cost and are presented in the balance sheet as a 
deduc � on from equity.

12. Auditor’s remunera on
The auditor’s remunera on for the audit of the Company is disclosed in note  7  to the consolidated  nancial statements.  Fees paid to the auditor for 
non-audit services to the Company are not required to be disclosed in the Company’s  nancial statements because consolidated  nancial statements 
are prepared which disclose such fees on a consolidated basis.
13. Transi on to FRS 101
For all periods up to and including the year ended 31 March 2015, the Company prepared its  nancial statements in accordance with previously 
extant United Kingdom generally accepted accoun ng prac ce (UK GAAP). These  nancial statements, for the year ended 31 March 201 6, are the 
 rst the Company has prepared in accordance with FRS 101.
Accordingly, the Company has prepared individual  nancial statements which comply with FRS 101 applicable for periods beginning on or a er 
1  April  2015  and the signi  cant accoun ng policies mee ng those requirements are described in the relevant notes.
In preparing these  nancial statements, the Company has started from an opening balance sheet as at 1 April 2014, the Company’s date of transi on 
to FRS 101, and made those changes in accoun ng policies and other restatements required for the  rst- me adop on for FRS 101.  As such, this note 
explains the principal adjustments made by the Company in resta ng its balance sheet as at 1 April 2014 prepared under previously extant UK GAAP 
and its previously published UK GAAP  nancial statements for the year ended 31 March 2015.

Independent Auditor’s report to the members of 
e2v technologies plc only (con nued)
Under the Companies Act 2006 we are required to report to you if, in our opinion:  
• adequate accoun ng records have not been kept by the parent company, or returns adequate for our audit have not been received 
from branches not visited by us; or  
• the parent company  nancial statements and the part of the Directors’ Remunera on Report to be audited are not in agreement 
with the accoun ng records and returns; or  
• certain disclosures of  Directors’ remunera on speci  ed by law are not made; or  
• we have not received all the informa on and explana ons we require for our audit .
 Under the Lis ng Rules we are required to review:  
• the  Directors’ statements, set out on pages  30 and  35, in rela on to going concern and longer-term viability; and   
• the part of the Corporate Governance Statement on page s 37 to 40 rela ng to the  Company’s compliance with the eleven 
provisions of the 2014 UK Corporate Governance Code speci  ed for our review.
We have nothing to report in respect of the above responsibili es.  
 Scope and responsibili es
As explained more fully in the Directors’ Responsibili es Statement set out on page  36, the  Directors are responsible for the 
prepara on of the  nancial statements and for being sa s  ed that they give a true and fair view.  A descrip on of the scope of an 
audit of  nancial statements is provided on the Financial Repor ng Council’s website at www.frc.org.uk/auditscopeukprivate. This 
report is made solely to the  Company’s members as a body and is subject to important explana ons and disclaimers regarding our 
responsibili es, published on our website at www.kpmg.com/uk/auditscopeukco2014a, which are incorporated into this report as if 
set out in full and should be read to provide an understanding of the purpose of this report, the work we have undertaken and the 
basis of our opinions.
Mike Barradell (Senior Statutory Auditor)  
for and on behalf of KPMG LLP, Statutory Auditor  
Chartered Accountants  
15 Canada Square 
London
E14 5GL

No � ce of Annual General Mee � ng (AGM) (con � nued)
  In order for a CREST proxy appointment or instruc � on made using the CREST service to be valid, the appropriate CREST message (a “CREST Proxy 
Instruc � on”) must be properly authen � cated in compliance with Euroclear UK & Ireland Limited’s speci  ca � ons and must contain the necessary 
informa � on, as described in the CREST Manual (available via www.euroclear.com). The message, regardless of whether it cons � tutes the 
appointment of a proxy or is an amendment to the instruc � on given to a previously appointed proxy must, in order to be valid, be transmi � ed 
so as to be received by Equini �  (ID RA19) no later than 9:00 a.m. on Monday 11 July 2016. For this purpose, the � me of receipt will be taken to 
be the � me (as determined by the � mestamp applied to the message by CREST Applica � ons Host) from which Equini �  is able to retrieve the

Special Resolu ons
Resolu on 14 – to disapply pre-emp on rights
Unless they are given an appropriate authority by shareholders, if the Directors wish to allot any of the unissued shares for cash or 
grant rights over shares or sell treasury shares for cash (other than pursuant to an employee share scheme) they must  rst o ﬀ er them 
to exis � ng shareholders in propor � on to exis � ng holdings. These are known as pre-emp � on rights.
The exis � ng disapplica � on of these statutory pre-emp � on rights, which was granted at the Annual General Mee � ng held on 15 July 2015 
will expire at the end of this year’s Annual General Mee � ng. Accordingly, resolu � on 14 in the no � ce of Annual General Mee � ng will be 
proposed, as a special resolu � on, to give the Directors power to allot shares without the applica � on of these statutory pre-emp � on 
rights:  rst, in rela � on to o ﬀ ers of equity securi � es by way of rights issue, open o ﬀ er or similar arrangements (save that in the case of 
an allotment pursuant to the authority conferred by paragraph 13.2 of resolu � on 13, such o ﬀ er shall be by way of rights issue only); 
and second, in rela � on to the allotment of equity securi � es for cash up to a maximum aggregate nominal amount of £1,091,910 
(represen � ng approximately 10% of the nominal value of the ordinary shares in issue on 13 May 2016 (excluding treasury shares)). 
These limits are in accordance with guidelines issued by the Pre-emp � on Group and the Investment Management Associa � on.
The Directors intend to adhere to the provisions in the Pre-Emp � on Group’s Statement of Principles, as updated in March 2015, and 
not to allot shares for cash on a non pre-emp � ve basis pursuant to the authority in resolu � on 13:
(i) in excess of an amount equal to 5% of the total issued ordinary share capital of the Company excluding treasury shares; or
(ii)  in excess of an amount equal to 7.5% of the total issued ordinary share capital of the Company excluding treasury shares within a 
rolling three-year period, without prior consulta � on with shareholders,
  in each case other than in connec � on with an acquisi � on or speci  ed capital investment which is announced contemporaneously 
with the allotment or which has taken place in the preceding six-month period and is disclosed in the announcement of the allotment.
The authority sought, and the limits set, by this resolu � on will also apply to a sale by the Company of any shares it holds as treasury 
shares. The Companies Act 2006 permits shares purchased by the Company out of distributable pro  ts to be held as treasury shares, 
which may then be cancelled, sold for cash or used to meet the Company’s obliga � ons under its employee share-based incen � ve 
schemes.
The powers conferred by this resolu � on will expire on 13 October 2017 or, if sooner, at the end of next year’s Annual General 
Mee � ng. However, the Company may make an o ﬀ er or agreement prior to the expiry of this power which would or might require 
equity securi � es to be allocated a � er the expiry of this power as if statutory pre-emp � on rights did not apply to such allotments. 
In this case, Directors will be permi � ed to allot such securi � es pursuant to such o ﬀ er or agreement as if this power had not expired.
Resolu on 15 – Company’s authority to purchase its own shares
At the Annual General Mee � ng of the Company held on 15 July 2015, the Company was authorised to make market purchases of 
up to 21,890,853 of its own ordinary shares. In the period from the Annual General Mee � ng on 15 July 2015 to 13 May 2016, the 
Company purchased 1,500,000 ordinary shares under this authority. As at 13 May 2016 such authority remained outstanding in 
rela � on to 20,390,853 ordinary shares. 
Resolu � on 15 in the no � ce of Annual General Mee � ng, which will be proposed as a special resolu � on, will authorise the Company to 
make market purchases of up to 21,838,215 ordinary shares. This equals 10% of the Company’s ordinary shares in issue on 13 May 2016 
(excluding treasury shares). The maximum price that may be paid shall be the higher of (i) 5% above the average of the middle market 
quota � ons for an ordinary share for the  ve business days immediately before the day on which the purchase is made and (ii) the higher 
of the price of the last independent trade and the highest current independent bid on the trading venue where the purchase is 
carried out or otherwise in accordance with Ar � cle 3(2) of the Commission Delegated Regula � on (EU) of 08.03.2016 supplemen � ng 
Regula � on (EU) No 596/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council with regard to regulatory technical standards for the 
condi � ons applicable to buy-back programmes and stabilisa � on measures. The minimum price which may be paid for each ordinary 
share shall be 5 pence (excluding of all expenses).

proposed.

no � ce, the Company must make a means of electronic vo � ng available to all shareholders for that mee � ng.
